docs.title: CONDITIONS
docs.text:
Conditions are always negative. Most effects that give conditions indicate when the conditions end (e.g., 'until the end of the target's next turn'). They can also be cleared with REFRESH.

Condition Description BLINDED BLINDED characters can only target and draw line of sight to adjacent spaces. DAZED DAZED characters receive +1 on all attacks, checks, and saves. DISARMED DISARMED characters can't make weapon attacks except for improvised weapon attacks. IMMOBILIZED IMMOBILIZED characters can't voluntarily move, but can still be subjected to forced and involuntary movement. MARKED When attacking a MARKED character, the attacker can choose to consume the MARK. Doing this clears MARKED and grants +1 on that attack roll. A character can only have one MARK at a time. SILENCED SILENCED characters can't use or RELEASE spells. SLOWED SLOWED characters can only move with their standard movement; they can't RUSH or use any other forms of voluntary movement.SLOWED PCs can only take their turns in PHASE DELAY. SLOWED NPCs have their next Initiative become 8 (this lasts until they've taken that turn and the condition ends). During rounds in which they are SLOWED, Bosses must take at least one of their turns during PHASE DELAY, even if they clear the condition before doing so. STUNNED STUNNED characters can perform either a standard action or a minor action on their turns, not both. Additionally, they can't FULL ATTACK or perform reactions, and their DODGE and A-DEF both count as 5. SUNDERED SUNDERED characters don't benefit from ARMOR or resistance. VULNERABLE VULNERABLE characters take double damage from Physical, Astral, Lunar, and Force sources. Stress and Discord are not affected. WEAKENED WEAKENED characters deal half damage when dealing Physical, Force, Astral, and Lunar. Stress and Discord are not affected. Their Summons and Traps are also unaffected.

docs.title: STATUSES
docs.text:
Statuses describe characters' current states, and can be positive or negative. Unlike conditions, they can't be removed unless specific actions are taken or their requirements no longer apply.

Status Description BLOODIED Characters are BLOODIED when they have half of their HP maximum or less (their BLOODIED level). BREAKING Characters are BREAKING when they have Stress equal to or exceeding half their STRESS CAP (their BREAKING point). ENGAGED When a character becomes adjacent to an enemy, they both gain the ENGAGED status as long as they are adjacent to one another. ENGAGED characters make ranged attacks at +1. If a character becomes ENGAGED by another character of the same SIZE or larger, their movement ends and they lose any unused movement. Characters cease to be ENGAGED when they are no longer adjacent to an enemy. FLYING Characters with flight can either take off, gaining the FLYING status, or land on the ground, clearing the status, as a free action once per turn. They can also choose to start combat scenes FLYING.While a character is FLYING, the following effects apply: > Non-thrown melee attacks from nonFLYING characters gain +2 against them. > They can move normally over and are immune to the effects of terrain, obstructions, and terrain features, but cannot benefit from or interact with them either. When flying over objects, they are considered to have their SIZE increased by the SIZE of whatever they are flying over for the purposes of determining line of sight and cover, as if they were climbing. > They cannot benefit from cover from terrain or objects. > When attacking nonFLYING characters, they treat their target's cover from terrain and objects as one step lower (hard cover becomes soft cover, soft cover becomes no cover). > They ignore ENGAGEMENT and don't cause ENGAGEMENT. > They don't trigger Traps but can still be affected by them. > They cease to be FLYING if they become PRONE. GRAPPLED GRAPPLED always involves at least two characters, both of whom receive the status. While GRAPPLED, the following effects apply: > Both characters are ENGAGED. > Neither character can take reactions. > The larger character can move normally. > The smaller character is IMMOBILIZED, but is dragged along by the larger character when they move, mirroring their movements and inheriting any special forms of movement like flight. > If the initiator is the same SIZE as the target, they count as the larger one during the turn in which they initiate the GRAPPLE. > Characters of the same SIZE can make a contested BULK check as a free action to see if they count as the larger one until this contest is repeated.GRAPPLED ends when one of the following occurs: > The characters are no longer adjacent to each other. > The initiator ends it as a free action. > The GRAPPLE target succeeds on a contested BULK check as a minor action. HIDDEN While a character is HIDDEN, enemies can only target them with AOEs or while adjacent to them. They are still visible on the combat map to players and the GM. The following things end HIDDEN: > The HIDDEN character uses a hostile effect (e.g., attacking or forcing a save) or uses INTERPOSE. > The HIDDEN character ends any turn within an enemy's line of sight unless they are either INVISIBLE or benefiting from cover against that enemy. > An enemy performs a successful SEARCH against them. INVISIBLE When making an attack against an INVISIBLE character, before any attack rolls are made, roll a d6. On a 1-3, the attack misses. INVISIBLE characters are still visible on the map to players and the GM. INVISIBLE lasts until the end of the scene unless stated otherwise. PRONE Attacks against PRONE targets gain +1 and PRONE characters always count as moving through difficult terrain. Unless they are IMMOBILIZED, PRONE characters can stand instead of making their standard movement, which ends this status. Standing doesn't count as a form of movement.

docs.title: TAGS
docs.text:
Abilities often have tags associated with them, such as Aura 2, Piercing, or Polymorph. When an ability has a tag, the effects of that tag apply to the effects of that ability. Some abilities don't have tags, but do have effects that have a tag, or that create objects or characters with the tag, as indicated in their description.

If an ability has a tag with a value of 'X', like Mana X, that means the amount can vary, but must be at least 1. Below is a list of tags and their effects.

Tag Description Accurate Attacks with this tag gain +1. Aetheric Attacks with this tag are made against A-DEF instead of DODGE. Arcing Abilities with this tag can be aimed over obstacles. They ignore line of sight as long as there is a vertical path to the target, although cover still applies. Armor Abilities with this tag represent suits of armor or similar defenses, many of which provide a bonus to ARMOR. A character can only have one ability with this tag equipped at a time. Aura X When activated, abilities with this tag affect indicated characters within X spaces of the user. A character can only have one Aura activated at a time and can change Auras 1/turn. Auto-Hit Attacks with this tag automatically hit without making an attack roll. Blast X Abilities with this tag have an AOE. It affects all targets within a radius of X spaces from the center space, including the center space. Cover and line of sight are calculated from the center space. Users can be affected by their own Blast. Burst X Affects all targets within a radius of X spaces from the edge of the spaces occupied by the target, including the target's spaces but excluding the target itself. Cover and line of sight are calculated from the edge of the spaces occupied by the target. If a Burst forms a zone, the zone moves with the target. Close Blast X Abilities with this tag have an AOE. It operates like a Blast, but:’ at least 1 space must be adjacent to the user’ the user can't be in the area’ cover and line of sight are calculated from the user. Consumable X Abilities with this tag can only be used X times per quest. Consumable abilities represent potions, elixirs, and other items that can be replenished. Enchantment Abilities with this tag modify other abilities. Enchantments can typically only be applied to specific types of abilities and can only be applied to one ability at a time. Additionally, each ability can only have one Enchantment at a time. Traits and talents can't be enchanted. Focus X Abilities with this tag cost X Focus to use. Homing Abilities with this tag ignore line of sight and the effects of cover. As long as the target is within Range and it is possible to reach them (i.e., they aren't in a box), they can be targeted. Inaccurate Attacks with this tag receive +1. Indirect Attacks with this tag ignore any from cover. Innate Abilities with this tag can't be destroyed or enchanted. They can't be chosen for destruction as the result of a wound roll. Limited X Abilities with this tag can only be used X times per quest. Limited abilities provide powerful effects that can't be replenished during a quest once used. Line X Abilities with this tag have an AOE. It affects all targets in a straight line with a length of X spaces and a width of 1 space, drawn directly away from you in any direction. Mana X Abilities with this tag cost X MP to use. Piercing Damage with this tag ignores ARMOR. Polymorph Abilities with this tag modify the target's form. A character can only be under the effect of one ability with this tag at a time, and any subsequent polymorph effects are automatically cancelled while they are under the effects of a polymorph. Pull X Abilities with this tag inflict a type of forced movement. On a hit, the target is moved X spaces directly toward the origin. Push X Abilities with this tag inflict a type of forced movement. On a hit, the target is moved X spaces directly away from the origin. Range X Abilities with this tag can be used on targets within X spaces. Reach X Abilities with this tag can be used on targets within X spaces. This tag also determines the range of the OPPORTUNITY ATTACK reaction. Reliable X Abilities with this tag always deal at least X damage, even if they would miss or deal less than X damage. Reliable damage inherits the ability's damage type and tags; however, Reliable damage does not count as a hit and doesn't trigger any effects that require a hit. Reloading Abilities with this tag must be reloaded after each use before they can be used again. This can be done using REFRESH and other abilities. Slide X Abilities with this tag inflict a type of forced movement. On a hit, the target is moved X spaces in any direction. Slow Abilities with this tag can only be activated as part of FULL ATTACK. Stressful X Abilities with this tag inflict X Stress on the user. Summon Abilities with this tag create one or more temporary characters under the control of another character, each of which has the Summon tag.By default, each character can only have one Summon per ability with this tag in play at a time. If a Summon is defeated or dismissed, a new one can be made using that same ability. Summons can't create Summons. Summons have the following statistics unless otherwise indicated: > SIZE 1/2 > HP 5 > DODGE/A-DEF 10 > SPEED 0 > SAVE TARGET = Summoner's SAVE TARGET > BULK / AGILITY / MIND / MAGIC 0Summons can only be created in free spaces that they could normally enter (they can't be summoned into impassable terrain, for example).Summons are characters with a standard action, standard movement, and minor action per round; however, they can't perform any actions unless they have an ability that lets them do so and can't perform a movement unless they have SPEED. Their turn is their summoner's turn, and if they can take actions or move, they can do so at any point in their summoner's turn.Summons are defeated if they are reduced to 0 HP. They can also be dismissed by their summoner as a free action. Summons last until dismissed or defeated, or until the end of the scene. Thrown X Abilities with this tag can be used to make a thrown attack, a melee attack made against a target within X spaces. Thrown attacks are affected by cover. If throwing a weapon, it lands in a space adjacent to the target (thrower's choice), and must be picked up as a free action while adjacent to it before it can be used again. Trap Abilities with this tag place traps - objects that modify spaces - or are traps themselves. They must be placed in a free adjacent space. They become armed at the end of the turn in which they are placed. Moving into or adjacent to a space occupied by a trap triggers it, activating its effects, after which it is removed from play.Traps are permanently HIDDEN, but can be automatically detected with SEARCH. You can attempt to disarm a trap by making an AGILITY check as a minor action when moving into or adjacent to its space (before it is triggered). On a success, the trap is removed from play without being activated. On a failure, it activates as normal. Unbreakable Abilities with this tag cannot be destroyed and can't be selected for destruction if there are nonUnbreakable options left. If an Unbreakable result is selected from a wound or overstress roll, it becomes a DAZED result instead. Unique Characters can only equip one copy of each ability with this tag at a time.

docs.title: 0: INTRODUCTION
docs.text: BEACON is a tabletop roleplaying game (TTRPG) inspired by the high fantasy stories of the Final Fantasy video games and the tactical gameplay of the Lancer and Dungeons & Dragons 4th Edition TTRPGs. High-action, tactical combat scenes are at the core of BEACON , supported by a streamlined and engaging narrative system that lets you get to the action quickly. Create unique and interesting characters, explore fantastical worlds with your friends, and confront the deadly dangers and obstacles that stand in your way!

docs.title: A World of Your Own
docs.text:
In BEACON , you create your own unique setting together, called a Reflection .

Games of BEACON take place in the Source, a wellspring of endless potential and stories. While the true nature of the Source is incomprehensibly complex, it is often represented as a giant crystal with infinite facets. Each facet is a different Reflection, and each Reflection is a unique reality.

While there are infinite stories that can be told within the Source, there are commonalities across its facets. The following are true of each Reflection:

  • Ø The world is filled with action and adventure .
  • Ø All things are composed of aether , a magical element that comes in many varieties, including astral and lunar forms.
  • Ø Magic is widely available and has been combined with technology to create magitech devices.
  • Ø There are beacons - people who are sources of great inspiration for others, whether they are heroes or villains.
  • Ø There is a recurring threat to the Reflection - the Scourge .
  • Ø Crystals hold some significance to the Reflection or its inhabitants.
  • Ø Ruins dot the landscape, ready to be explored.

The GM and players work together to define the specific details of the Reflection in which their game takes place, including its history, peoples, and cultures. This process is detailed in Chapter 10: Game Master's Guide (p. 223).

docs.title: Two Modes of Play
docs.text:
BEACON features two modes of play narrative play and combat . While playing, you will move between these two modes, which each have their own unique set of rules.

During narrative play, you tell stories about your characters and the world in which they live. Narrative play is rules-light, allowing players to shape the narrative without getting bogged down by mechanics.

In combat play, your characters - customized and equipped in countless ways - enter battle. Combat play is tactical and rules-heavy, with plenty of scope for unique builds and playstyles.

docs.title: You are a Beacon
docs.text:
Your characters in the game are known as beacons. Beacons are powerful heroes who help and inspire others. Every Reflection has its own unique take on what beacons are and what they do.

BuildinG BeaconS

runninG tHe Game

Participants in BEACON take on one of two roles: either that of a player or that of the game master ( GM ).

The goal of all participants is to tell a shared story, and to have fun doing so. Each player creates a single player character ( PC ) - a heroic figure called a ' beacon ' - and explores the game through that character's story. The GM, on the other hand, controls all of the non-player characters ( NPCs ), sets up combat scenes, and helps shape the narrative.

docs.title: CORE PRINCIPLES
docs.text:
BEACON has six core principles:

  • 1 The well-being and fun of the group, including both the players and the GM, is the top priority.
  • 2 Specific text takes precedent over general text.
  • 3 BEACON does not model reality or real-life physics, and is not meant to.
  • 4 Narrative play and combat play are distinct modes of play. The ability to do something in one does not automatically grant the ability to do it in the other.
  • 5 In combat play, players can do anything their abilities allow, even if it doesn't make narrative sense.
  • 6 Always round up to the nearest whole number.

docs.title: GENERAL TEXT VS. SPECIFIC TEXT
docs.text:
General text includes basic rules of the game, such as 'The FIGHT action is used to make a melee or improvised weapon attack.'

Specific text is more granular or detailed than general text. For example, the SLOW tag specifies that, 'Abilities with this tag can only be activated as part of FULL ATTACK . ' This means that a SLOW weapon can't be used as part of the FIGHT action, because the text of the SLOW tag is more specific than the text of the FIGHT action.

docs.title: COMBAT AND NARRATIVE SCENES
docs.text:
BEACON ' s gameplay is split into scenes . A scene is a series of events that focus on a person, place, or challenge. Each scene is either a narrative scene or a combat scene , falling under the rules of either combat play or narrative play .

The GM determines when one scene ends and another begins, and whether the scenes are narrative or combat. But anyone can suggest or request a scene, and you are encouraged to do so.

Combat scenes use the rules for combat play (p. 41). These scenes feature important fights and battles. Not every fight is worthy of a combat scene; only those that are important or tactically challenging move into combat play. A simple street fight or barroom brawl, for example, wouldn't start a combat scene. A fight on a crumbling bridge against a horde of demons, or a climactic showdown with an archnemesis would be worthy of a combat scene.

Example: An angry necromancer has performed a ritual in a nearby cemetery, creating a continuous stream of undead soldiers that attack nearby towns. The beacons are asked to stop the necromancer and break the ritual. The GM sets up a combat scene with the beacons fighting in a misty cemetery against undead hordes and a necromancer riding an animated mausoleum!

Narrative scenes, on the other hand, use the rules for narrative play (p. 22). Any scene that isn't a combat scene is considered a narrative scene. These scenes involve challenges that are resolved by rolling dice (called 'skill checks') or roleplaying. Small-scale fights can even happen during narrative play, but these fights are resolved just like any other challenge that happens during narrative play, using skill checks and roleplaying instead of the combat play rules.

Example: The beacons need to get to a floating island and the only way to get there is with an airship. They don't have one, so they ask the GM for a scene with the Artificer's Guild. The GM sets up a scene in which the beacons meet the guildmaster directly. The beacons attempt to convince the guildmaster to let them borrow an airship, using a mix of roleplaying and skill checks to determine how successful their attempts are.

docs.title: STRUCTURE OF PLAY
docs.text:
The gameplay of BEACON revolves around quests (p. 241). Quests are missions, tasks, or jobs provided to the beacons by the GM. Quests contain both combat and narrative scenes, connecting them to tell stories. The quests that your characters participate in form the body of your campaign , which is the overarching story of your characters.

For example, your group's primary motivation might be to defeat a great evil. In order to gain the strength, allies, and resources to do so, they might need to

undertake a number of quests, preparing themselves for the final showdown with their foe.

The time between quests uses the rules for narrative play. During this time, the players collaboratively tell their beacons' stories and explore the world.

When the players are ready to begin a new quest, they equip their beacons with abilities they've unlocked that they think will best suit the upcoming quest and the combat scenes within it.

When the beacons return from a quest, they level up (p. 14) and become more powerful. This allows them to combine abilities and equipment from multiple classes (p. 84) to create unique playstyles and character configurations.

docs.title: DICE
docs.text:
During both narrative play and combat, players roll dice to determine success, failure, and other interesting outcomes. BEACON uses two types of dice: 20-sided dice ( d20 ) and 6-sided dice ( d6 ). The rules sometimes call for a d3 , which can be represented with a d6. A result of 1-2 equals 1, 3-4 equals 2, and 5-6 equals 3.

A number in front of the type of die indicates how many dice of that type to roll. 3d6 means you roll 3 six-sided dice.

docs.title: ATTACKS, CHECKS, AND SAVES
docs.text: There are three main types of dice rolls in BEACON : attack rolls , checks , and saves . They each use a single d20. Any time you're making one of these rolls, roll a d20 and add the appropriate modifiers to the result - bonuses or penalties to the roll based on beneficial or disadvantageous situations. The final result is your total for the roll.

docs.title: ATTACKS
docs.text: Attacks are hostile actions taken against other characters in combat play. They are usually made with weapons, spells, or skills. When attacking, you add your beacon's GRIT score to the roll. See Chapter 5: Combat Play (p. 41) for more information.

docs.title: CHECKS
docs.text:
Checks are rolls to determine how successful challenging actions are. There are two types of checks that you might make: skill checks and ability checks . To make a check of either type, you roll a d20 and add any relevant modifiers. To succeed, you need a total of 10 or more (after modifiers).

Skill checks are used in narrative play. If one of a character's background skills (p. 12) would be helpful for the roll they're making, or they can invoke their title (p. 11), they can get a bonus on to the roll. See Chapter 4: Narrative Play (p. 22) for more information.

Ability checks , by contrast, are used in combat play. They use the character's relevant ability score -BULK , AGILITY , MIND , or MAGIC - as a modifier (p. 49).

During combat play, characters sometimes need to make contested checks . In a contested check, the two relevant parties each roll an ability check. Whoever gets the highest total succeeds, with ties going to the one who attacked or initiated the action.

docs.title: SAVES
docs.text: Saves are rolls made to resist effects during combat play. Effects that prompt a save indicate which of the target's ability scores to use as a modifier. Each character has a SAVE TARGET , which is the total their opponents must meet or exceed when rolling saves. When there is no SAVE TARGET indicated, it defaults to 10 .

docs.title: MODIFIERS
docs.text:
There are three types of modifiers that can affect rolls, increasing or decreasing their results:

  • Ø Accuracy ( )
  • Ø Difficulty ( )
  • Ø Static modifiers (+1, -4, etc.).

Bonuses from your beacon's ability scores and GRIT count as static modifiers.

docs.title: ACCURACY AND DIFFICULTY
docs.text:
Various effects can apply Accuracy or Difficulty to a d20 roll.

For each or , roll 1d6 and take the single highest result out of the dice rolled. If rolling with , this number is added to the total as a positive modifier . If rolling with , it is subtracted from the total as a negative modifier . For example, if you are rolling with 2 , you would roll 2d6 and keep the single highest result out of all the dice. If you rolled a 2 and a 4, you would keep the 4.

Rolls can be affected by multiple instances of or , although they cancel each other out on a one-toone basis. For example, a roll could receive 4 and 2 ; however, the 2 would cancel out 2 , leaving the roll with 2 . Always determine the final amount of or before rolling any dice.

An individual roll can't benefit from more than 6 or .

docs.title: 2: ANATOMY OF A BEACON
docs.text:
This chapter walks through the steps of creating a character and outlines the various components that define them.

In BEACON , the characters created and portrayed by the players are special individuals known as 'beacons' . They are called this because of the way they act like shining lights to others. There is no one way that beacons act or conduct themselves; no matter what, they always find themselves in positions where they can inspire or help others.

The precise characteristics that make someone a beacon differ between Reflections. In one Reflection, beacons might be mystically empowered individuals born under a strange star. In another, they might be students with an abundance of charisma.

Beacons don't need a reason to be special in your game. The fact they are controlled by a player already makes them special, and grants them the opportunity to influence and change the story as it's told. Your game could be about a band of heroes destined to save the world, or it could be about a found family, fighting to keep itself safe.

The only constant across all Reflections is that beacons inspire people around them. Even those who are cowardly or timid have the potential and opportunity, as a group, to give hope to others.

Chapter 10: Game Master's Guide details some example Reflections and the roles of beacons within them (p. 233).

docs.title: CHARACTER CREATION
docs.text:
This section will guide you through the steps of creating a beacon.

Every beacon has a character level (p. 14). Character levels represent the overall growth and power of a beacon. Higher-level beacons have more abilities available to them, and can therefore handle a wider variety of situations.

Your beacon begins at character level 1 . At level 1, they have:

  • Ø a name and a title
  • Ø three rank 1 background skills (p. 12)
  • Ø 2 ability points (p. 12)
  • Ø three rank 1 talents (p. 13)
  • Ø an ancestry (p. 13)
  • Ø one class rank (p. 13)
  • Ø access to all basic equipment and techniques (p. 13)
  • Ø an appearance (p. 13).

Once you have finished these steps, you will determine your beacon's attributes, which are values used in combat play (p. 14).

docs.title: Choose a name for your beacon.
docs.text:
Beacons can have any sort of name, from the mundane to the grandiose. Alternatively, you can decide this later. You might not have an idea for a name yet, but might think of one after picking your background skills or ancestry. There are also plenty of random name generators online that you can use for inspiration.

Example: Shawn is creating her first beacon. She likes the name Dhalia, so she uses it for her character.

docs.title: Choose a title for your beacon.
docs.text:
When the stories of your character and their fellow beacons become legend, how will they be remembered? What will they be called when their name falls into obscurity and all that survives is their deeds?

People recognize your beacon by this title, even if they don't know their name. Titles can reference anything from a fighting style to a physical trait or even an aesthetic.

Example titles: The Green Knight, the Herald of Silence, the Bosstown Bludgeon, Moonfang, the Timeless Bard.

Whenever you make a skill check during narrative play, you can invoke your beacon's title before rolling to gain a +2 bonus . T o invoke a title, the action in question must be something that contributes to the legend of your character's title. Think of a story being told about your beacon, their name lost to history and only their title remaining. Would this make it into the story?

Example: Shawn likes the idea of playing someone smart; a knowledge-seeker. She gives Dhalia the title of 'the All-Knowing' . Shawn can invoke this title when doing something that contributes to the legacy of 'the All-Knowing' beacon. For example, if Dhalia is making a skill check to piece together the conspiracy behind the Day of Shadows, she can invoke her title to gain a +2 bonus to the roll. If Dhalia is making a skill check to climb a mountain, on the other hand, being all-knowing is less likely to be helpful, and couldn't be invoked.

The GM decides whether a title can be invoked or not. Players are encouraged to find creative explanations for why a beacon's title might apply, but they're not meant to be used in every situation.

If you find that your title is too easy to invoke, consider rephrasing it to limit its scope.

Example: Delmar's beacon is Dmitri, 'the Demigod' . After playing a few sessions, he realizes that 'the Demigod' can be invoked in every situation. Delmar rephrases the title as 'the Demigod of Determination', which puts some limits on when it can be invoked.

docs.title: WRITING YOUR LEGEND
docs.text:
One way you can use titles is as a way of documenting the legend of your beacon. Whenever you invoke their title, write down what it was being used for and what the outcome was. When you're finished playing that character, look over everything that was written down. This is the foundation for the legends told about your beacon for generations to come.

docs.title: BACKGROUND SKILLS
docs.text:
At level 1, create three rank 1 background skills.

Background skills are words or brief phrases that represent a beacon's history and training, and provide bonuses to skill checks. Background skills have three ranks. When you make a skill check in narrative play and one of your background skills is relevant, you get +1 on your roll for each rank you have in that skill. Each skill check can only benefit from one background skill, which must be decided before rolling.

Background skills can be anything, so make sure they're evocative. Instead of just ' Acrobat ' , make it something interesting like, ' Acrobat Performer for the Demon Circus ' .

Example background skills: Will of the Source, TrollWrestling Champion, An Eye for Lies, Royal Assassin.

When creating a background skill, think about what situations it might be relevant in. If it seems like it would apply to every skill check you might make, you should narrow its focus more.

Every time your beacon levels up they get a background skill point. These points can be used to either increase the rank of an existing background skill (to a maximum of rank 3 ), or create a new background skill at rank 1.

Example: Shawn creates a background skill 'Truthseeker' for Dhalia. This can be used any time Dhalia is trying to learn the truth about something, whether researching in books or detecting lies.

Shawn also thinks that Dhalia should know lightbased magic, so she creates the background skill 'Disciple of the Sun' , which would apply whenever she uses magic.

Finally, Shawn creates the background skill 'Multipurpose Clothing' because she likes the idea of Dhalia having clothes with secondary benefits, like a cloak that can be used as a paraglider. She would apply this background skill whenever she can think of a fun way to solve a problem with clothes.

docs.title: ABILITY SCORES
docs.text:
At level 1, assign 2 ability points.

Your beacon has four ability scores that affect their attributes and actions in combat play:

  • Ø BULK
  • Ø AGILITY
  • Ø MIND
  • Ø MAGIC

Ability scores range from +0 to +6 , and give bonuses in combat play. By default, they start at +0 .

Each ability score also provides bonuses to some of your character's other attributes (p. 14). For example, AGILITY affects the character's DODGE and SPEED .

Assigning an ability point to an ability score increases it by +1. At level 1, this means you can have two ability scores at +1 each, or one ability score at +2.

docs.title: Bulk
docs.text:
BULK determines how tough and sturdy a character is in combat. You gain:

  • Ø +2 HP for every point of BULK
  • Ø +1 RECOVERY for every two points of BULK

docs.title: Agility
docs.text:
AGILITY determines how fast and evasive a character is in combat. You gain:

  • Ø +1 DODGE for every point of AGILITY
  • Ø +1 SPEED for every two points of AGILITY

docs.title: Mind
docs.text:
MIND determines how much mental strain a character can handle, and how well they can remember their training in combat. You gain:

  • Ø +1 STRESS CAP for every point of MIND
  • Ø +1 MEMORY for every two points of MIND

docs.title: Magic
docs.text:
MAGIC determines how magically adept a character is in combat. You gain:

  • Ø +1 AETHERIC DEFENSE (A-DEF) for every point of MAGIC
  • Ø +1 MP for every two points of MAGIC

Example: Shawn wants Dhalia to be a spellcaster with a variety of spells, so she assigns 1 ability point to MIND and 1 to MAGIC .

Delmar wants Dmitri to be as tough as possible, so he assigns 2 ability points to BULK .

docs.title: TALENTS
docs.text:
At level 1, choose three rank 1 talents. See p. 202 for the full list of talents and their abilities.

While many of the abilities available to beacons are tied to their class (see below), talents are sets of abilities that can be acquired by any beacon and that don't need to be equipped. Once your beacon has learned a talent, they will always have access to any abilities unlocked by their ranks in that talent.

Each talent has three ranks , each with its own ability. When your beacon first gains a talent, they get access to it at rank 1. If you assign additional points to that talent, you can get that talent's rank 2 and eventually its rank 3 ability.

Beacons gain additional talents and can even change their talent choices when they level up (p. 14).

Example: Shawn wants to pick magical-sounding talents for Dhalia. She picks the Archmage , Enchanter , and Leyline Walker talents because they sound like they will assist with magic. She doesn't spend much time reviewing all the options because she knows she can change them later.

Delmar, on the other hand, carefully reviews all the talents before making his decision. He chooses the Brawler talent because it enhances unarmed combat and he wants Dmitri to fight with his fists. He also wants to protect his allies, so he picks the Knight talent. Finally, he wants Dmitri to be highly mobile, so he chooses the Traceur talent.

docs.title: ANCESTRY
docs.text:
Choose an ancestry. See p. 68 for the full list of ancestries.

Your beacon's ancestry describes their heritage or species. Ancestry determines a beacon's SIZE and gives access to a list of ancestry traits . Whenever your character goes on a quest, they can choose to equip one of their ancestry traits.

Ancestries can also be used as collections of common traits, rather than literal descriptions of how characters look or act. For example, the avian ancestry allows for flight, but an avian character doesn't have to be a literal bird-person; maybe they're a human that comes from a culture where jetpacks are common.

Example: The elves in Shawn's favorite stories are known for being magically gifted, so she plans on making Dhalia an elf. She reads the elf ancestry traits and likes the Elven Accuracy one. She doesn't need to pick a trait until Dhalia goes on a quest, but she knows she'll probably use Elven Accuracy.

docs.title: CLASS
docs.text:
At level 1, choose 1 rank in any class. See p. 84 for the full list of available classes.

Classes represent specialized approaches to combat, like a Thunderclaw's electrical fighting style or a Phoenix's burning spells. Classes unlock equipment and abilities that beacons can equip for quests.

Each class has three ranks, with each rank unlocking additional equipment and abilities.

As they level up, beacons gain ranks in multiple classes. The equipment, techniques, and jobs they unlock can be mixed and matched in a huge number of combinations.

docs.title: Job
docs.text:
Each class also provides a job unique to that class. Jobs provide the starting values for a beacon's attributes (p. 14) and their equipment slots (p. 16). A class's job is unlocked upon reaching rank 1 in that class.

Every job also has a limit break - a powerful, scene-changing ability unique to that class. Your beacon can only perform one limit break per quest. If you use a limit break from one job and later change jobs within the same quest, you don't get to use the new job's limit break - you've already used your one limit break for that quest. Beacons regain the ability to use a limit break after a Long Rest (p. 61).

Example: Shawn picks the Equinox class for Dhalia, gaining the Equinox job and unlocking the rank 1 Exobomb and Scar spells. She likes that the class focuses on long-distance spell attacks, as well as the description mentioning sun aether, which connects to her background skill 'Disciple of the Sun' .

docs.title: BASIC EQUIPMENT AND TECHNIQUES
docs.text:
All beacons have access to a wide array of weapons , support items , skills , and spells that they can equip right from the very beginning. They aren't limited to equipping only abilities from their current job.

You can find this standard gear in Chapter 9: Basic Equipment and Techniques (p. 216). You don't need to choose any until you're ready to go on a quest, but you might want to look at them now to get a feel for what's available.

docs.title: APPEARANCE
docs.text:
The last step in creating your beacon is deciding their appearance - what they, their equipment, and their abilities look like. It's totally up to you - you can describe them any way you want, regardless of the art and flavor text in this book.

The only limitation is that your description can't grant mechanical benefits in combat play. You can't give your character see-through skin and argue they should always be invisible. Beyond that restriction, describe whatever you want: Give your beacon wings that let them fly around during narrative play. Let them move around the world in a wheelchair. Have them wield weapons made of solid ice. Describe a photon axe as a greatsword.

Describe the character you see yourself playing. The information in this book is just intended to provide inspiration - it isn't absolute truth. There are infinite worlds in which your story can take place. Anything is possible.

Example: Shawn finishes character creation by deciding that Dhalia is a pale elf with long dark hair and golden eyes. Her spells flash with bright light when used, their color and luminosity changing depending on her emotions. With that, she's ready to begin playing!

docs.title: LEVELS
docs.text:
Each beacon has a character level , which represents their overall growth and strength.

Whenever you finish a quest, whether you were successful or not, your beacon gains another character level. This is called leveling up. The maximum character level for beacons is 12.

docs.title: LEVELING UP
docs.text:
Whenever your beacon gains a character level, they gain:

  • Ø 1 rank in a new or existing class
  • Ø 1 ability point
  • Ø 1 background skill point
  • Ø 1 talent rank or a new rank 1 talent

docs.title: GRIT
docs.text:
GRIT represents the combat experience that beacons gain when they increase their character level.

Starting at character level 2 and then at every second level after that (i.e., levels 4, 6, 8, etc.), beacons gain +1 GRIT . GRIT is a passive bonus that applies to several other attributes. Each point of GRIT provides the following:

  • Ø +1 HP
  • Ø +1 SAVE TARGET
  • Ø +1 to all attack rolls
  • Ø +1 MEMORY

docs.title: CHANGING CHOICES
docs.text:
Whenever your beacon gains a level, you may do one or both of the following:

  • Ø Reassign any number of ranks from one talent to another.
  • Ø Reassign any number of ranks from one class to another.

docs.title: ATTRIBUTES
docs.text: In addition to their talents, background skills, and so on, beacons have several attributes that are used in combat play. They are determined by a character's level, job, ancestry, talents, ability scores, and equipped gear and techniques.

docs.title: SIZE
docs.text:
SIZE determines how many spaces a character (or object) takes up on a grid and how they interact with cover. Chapter 5: Combat Play (p. 41) covers how this works in greater detail. In an abstract sense, SIZE represents how much space or control a character exerts on the battlefield; it does not indicate exactly how tall or how heavy they are.

SIZE 1/2 and SIZE 1 characters both occupy 1 space, SIZE 2 characters occupy an area of 2 x 2 spaces, and SIZE 3 characters occupy an area of 3 x 3 spaces.

Beacons can be anywhere between SIZE 1/2 and SIZE 3 . This is determined by their ancestry.

docs.title: SCOPE
docs.text: SCOPE is the maximum number of grid spaces within which a character can detect HIDDEN characters, attack with spells, and use certain other abilities.

docs.title: ARMOR
docs.text:
ARMOR reduces incoming damage by an amount equal to its value. ARMOR does not affect Discord, which is a nonstandard damage type, or Stress, which is not considered damage.

Characters cannot have more than 4 ARMOR .

docs.title: SAVE TARGET
docs.text: When one character forces another to make a save, the character making the save must equal or exceed the initiating character's SAVE TARGET to succeed.

docs.title: HP AND WOUNDS
docs.text:
Every character has a pool of hit points ( HP ). Points are subtracted from this pool when they take damage.

Characters have a BLOODIED value , which is half of their maximum HP (rounded up). When a character's current HP is equal to or less than their BLOODIED value, they are considered BLOODIED (p. 63).

When a character reaches 0 HP , they take a Wound . When they take a Wound, their player resets their HP , carrying over any excess damage, and makes a wound roll to see what additional penalties they suffer. Beacons are taken out of a fight when they accumulate 4 Wounds . This is known as their WOUND CAP .

See Chapter 5: Combat Play (p. 41) for additional information on HP, and Wounds and Overstress (p. 60) for more information about Wounds.

docs.title: RECOVERIES
docs.text:
Each beacon has a pool of RECOVERIES , which represent the resources they have available to heal themselves and repair their equipment. They can heal themselves by spending RECOVERIES using the REFRESH action and other abilities.

Beacons start with a maximum number of RECOVERIES determined by their job, which increases with BULK . They refresh their pool of recoveries when they take a Long Rest (p. 61).

docs.title: DODGE
docs.text: DODGE represents how hard it is for attacks to hit a character. To hit a target, the result of the attack roll must equal or exceed the target's DODGE .

docs.title: SPEED
docs.text: SPEED is how fast a character can move. When a character takes a standard movement during their turn, they can move a number of spaces equal to their SPEED (p. 54).

docs.title: STRESS CAP AND OVERSTRESS
docs.text:
Stress is a special type of harm that characters can take (p. 58). Stress is accumulated through mental and physical strain, like suffering psychic attacks or performing tiring combat maneuvers.

When a character takes Stress, it accumulates until it exceeds their STRESS CAP . If a character goes over their STRESS CAP , they take an Overstress. Their player resets their Stress, carrying over any excess Stress; and make an overstress roll to see what additional penalties they suffer. Beacons are taken out of a fight when they accumulate 4 Overstresses , which is known as their OVERSTRESS CAP .

Characters have a BREAKING point , which is half of their STRESS CAP (rounded up). When a character's current Stress is equal to or higher than their BREAKING point, they are considered BREAKING .

See Wounds and Overstress (p. 60) for additional information.

docs.title: MEMORY
docs.text: A character's MEMORY limits the maximum number of techniques they can equip. Each technique has its own MEMORY cost - the combined value of all of equipped techniques cannot exceed the character's MEMORY .

docs.title: AETHERIC DEFENSE (A-DEF)
docs.text: AETHERIC DEFENSE ( A-DEF ) is how hard a character is to hit with Aetheric attacks. Aetheric attacks target the aether that makes up a being, and they can't be avoided like normal attacks. These attacks - magical attacks from abilities with the Aetheric tag - must equal or exceed the target's A-DEF to hit.

docs.title: MANA POINTS (MP)
docs.text: Mana points (MP) are a pool of magical energy that can be spent to use certain abilities. To use one of these abilities, a character must have the indicated amount of MP available, and it is spent once the ability is activated. Beacons can restore MP in combat with the REFRESH action.

docs.title: ABILITIES
docs.text: Beacons use a wide variety of abilities to achieve victory in combat scenes. Abilities include traits, equipment, talents, and techniques. In general, anything that can be used in a combat scene is considered an ability.

docs.title: Stacking Abilities
docs.text:
Each character can only benefit from one instance of any given ability or effect at a time. Put another way, subsequent instances of abilities and effects don't stack on top of themselves.

For example, the Sniper talent's rank 2 ability, ZERO IN , gives +1 on ranged attacks every time you miss, and stacks until you finally hit with a ranged attack. Conversely, the SHOCKING GRASP spell, which prevents targets from performing reactions until the end of their next turn when they're hit, wouldn't extend its effect across additional turns if they were hit by SHOCKING GRASP again before the original effect expired.

docs.title: TRAITS
docs.text:
Traits are abilities that reinforce a beacon's identity and playstyle. Traits come from a beacon's ancestry (p. 13) and equipped job (p. 13).

Traits can provide either passive benefits or effects that need to be activated. Some traits provide additional abilities, like the Riftblade job's special RIFTCUTTER weapon. Beacons' equipped traits are always available and cannot be destroyed.

docs.title: EQUIPMENT
docs.text: Equipment is the weapons, armor, and tools that a beacon chooses to bring on a quest, and it has a significant impact on their combat performance. Equipment is broken down into two categories: weapons and support items . Equipment is usually selected when preparing for a quest.

docs.title: Equipment Slots
docs.text: Each job provides a different number of weapon slots and support slots . These determine how many weapons and support items the beacon can equip. Weapons can only be equipped in weapon slots, and support items can only be equipped in support slots. Each slot is also suitable for equipment of a certain size LIGHT , MAIN , or HEAVY - or smaller.

docs.title: Equipment Size
docs.text:
Like equipment slots, weapons and support items come in three sizes , from smallest to largest: LIGHT , MAIN , and HEAVY .

You can only equip a weapon or support item into a slot if the equipment is the same size as the slot or smaller. For example, if you have a MAIN weapon slot, you can equip either a MAIN or a LIGHT weapon to it.

docs.title: Free Equipment
docs.text: Some equipment can be equipped for free . Free equipment doesn't take up a slot when equipped; however, only one copy of each piece of equipment can be equipped for free at a time. You can't have multiple free versions of the same equipment. You can have multiple different pieces of equipment equipped for free, though, and something equipped for free can still be equipped in other slots.

docs.title: Weapons
docs.text: Weapons are the primary way that beacons attack their foes. Weapons can be either melee weapons or ranged weapons . Melee weapons make melee attacks, and ranged weapons make ranged attacks. See Chapter 5: Combat Play (p. 41) for additional information on how different sorts of attacks work.

docs.title: WEAPON TYPE
docs.text:
In addition to a size, each weapon has one of the following types :

  • Ø ARTIFACT : Wands, staves, and other magical implements. Artifacts often have the Aetheric tag.
  • Ø BLADE : Swords, axes, and daggers of any size. Blades are basic, balanced weapons.
  • Ø BOW : Bows and crossbows. Bows are typically ranged and often have the Arcing tag, allowing them to fire over obstacles.
  • Ø CLUB : Maces, warhammers, and other blunt weapons. These weapons are often Slow or Inaccurate, but hit hard. Natural weapons like claws also count as clubs.
  • Ø LONGARM : Spears, javelins, and other weapons with an extended reach.
  • Ø MAGITECH : Magitech weapons are any that combine technology and magic. Shardguns, which are firearms that shoot blasts of magical energy from specialized crystals, are the most common sort of magitech.

docs.title: LINKED WEAPONS
docs.text:
Weapon slots that have a symbol between two weapon sizes (e.g., LIGHT LIGHT ) can hold two linked weapons of the indicated sizes. These two weapons form a linked pair . When you attack with a linked weapon, you can also attack with the weapon it's linked to as part of the same action - as long as you haven't already done so as part of the same action. This second

attack is called a linked attack . Each linked pair can only trigger one linked attack per turn. You can make a linked attack even if the weapon would normally be used in a different phase. This excludes Slow attacks. Linked attacks don't benefit from bonus damage.

A weapon can only be in one linked pair at a time. Both weapons count as linked to each other. Each weapon in the linked pair counts as a separate weapon and can benefit from a separate Enchantment ; however, if one is destroyed, so is the other.

docs.title: WHAT DO LINKED WEAPONS LOOK LIKE?
docs.text: Linked weapons can be interpreted a number of ways. They might be depicted as dual-wielded weapons; weapons literally connected by links; or weapons fused together, like a double-bladed sword.

docs.title: Support Items
docs.text: Support items are the armor, shields, potions, and tools that beacons can equip for quests. Support items often provide defensive bonuses or utility abilities.

docs.title: TECHNIQUES
docs.text:
Beacons learn a wide variety of battle techniques that affect the way they approach combat. Offensive spells, unique ways of moving, and changes to one's own body are all types of techniques a beacon can equip for a quest. Techniques are broken down into two categories: spells and skills.

Techniques cost a certain amount of MEMORY to equip. A beacon's available MEMORY is determined by their equipped job, and increased by their MIND . You can only equip a technique if there is sufficient MEMORY available.

Techniques are usually equipped when preparing for a quest.

docs.title: Free Techniques
docs.text: Like equipment, some techniques can be equipped for free. Free techniques don't take up any MEMORY ; however, only one copy of a given technique can be equipped for free at a time. You can't have multiple free versions of the same technique. You can have multiple different techniques equipped for free, though.

docs.title: Spells
docs.text: Spells are magical abilities. Not every spell requires the caster to spend MP, but they do require the caster to be able to manipulate aether. Because of this, the SILENCED condition (p. 62) prevents characters from casting spells.

docs.title: Skills
docs.text: Unlike spells, skills are abilities that don't require the user to manipulate aether. They are usually nonmagical in nature, but some do cost MP to activate, like the shapeshifter's SCOUT FORM . These skills draw their mana directly from the user's body, with no active manipulation of aether needed. Because of this, skills are unaffected by the SILENCED condition.

docs.title: RESOURCES
docs.text: Beacons tend to acquire various resources during their adventures. Some resources are used for combat play only, like TEMP HP and FOCUS , while others are only used in narrative play, like GOLD and RESIDUUM . There are also supplies , that can provide benefits in both narrative and combat play.

docs.title: COMBAT RESOURCES Temporary HP
docs.text:
TEMPORARY HP (TEMP HP) is a separate pool of HP outside of a character's normal HP . Whenever a character's HP is reduced by damage, points are taken from their TEMP HP first. Any remaining damage is subtracted from their HP as normal. TEMP HP can't be restored by effects that restore normal HP .

TEMP HP can come from various sources, including techniques, equipment, and other abilities. Separate instances of TEMP HP don't stack; if a character already has TEMP HP , a second source of TEMP HP would only apply if it is greater than the current amount of TEMP HP they have. For example, if a character with 2 TEMP HP uses an ability that would give them 4 TEMP HP , this new, greater source of TEMP HP replaces the first one - they end up with 4 TEMP HP , not 6 .

docs.title: Focus
docs.text:
FOCUS is a temporary resource gained during combat scenes. It can be spent for certain effects, like the INTERPOSE reaction . It starts at 0, and has no maximum. All FOCUS is lost at the end of each scene.

docs.title: Gold
docs.text:
Instead of keeping track of every piece of currency your character is carrying, BEACON uses an abstract form of currency called GOLD . GOLD represents the resources and influence that are available to your beacon. The actual currency used in your Reflection might be emerald chips, paper bills, or credits, but for simplicity's sake these are all treated the same way.

Beacons are assumed to have enough resources to cover basic needs like food and housing, and they always have access to their starting and unlocked equipment. GOLD is only used for downtime activities, purchasing SUPPLIES (see below), and in narrative scenes.

In narrative scenes, GOLD is only used for purchases that are meaningful and impactful. A beacon doesn't need to spend GOLD when staying at an inn or purchasing a drink at the tavern; however, staying in the penthouse suite of the Golden Goose Casino might cost GOLD , since doing so is a luxury reserved only for the wealthy.

GOLD can be acquired through downtime activities like PURSUE PROFESSION or as a reward at the end of quests. Each beacon can have a maximum of 10 GOLD at a time.

docs.title: WHY A GOLD LIMIT?
docs.text: The GOLD limit is to encourage players to spend their GOLD more often, instead of hoarding it. GMs are welcome to change the limit to better suit their game.

docs.title: Residuum
docs.text:
RESIDUUM is a byproduct of the destruction of magical items. It is dense in aether and can be used to modify other magical items. RESIDUUM is created with the DISENCHANT LOOT downtime activity. (p. 27).

  • Ø 1 RESIDUUM : Reroll any one loot crate slot.
  • Ø 2 RESIDUUM : Reroll any one loot crate slot and choose a specific type for the slot (weapon, support item, skill, or spell).
  • Ø 2 RESIDUUM : Reroll any one loot crate slot. The rerolled slot will be one level rarer than the original result (Uncommon > Rare > Legendary).

docs.title: Supplies
docs.text:
Supplies are miscellaneous items that beacons can bring on quests, like a well-cooked meal from the tavern or a potion from the local alchemist. They provide temporary benefits and don't require equipment slots or MEMORY to equip. SUPPLIES can be earned as quest rewards, through narrative play, most often with the SHOP downtime activity. You can find the full list of SUPPLIES in Appendix A: Shops and Supplies (p. 346).

When preparing for a quest, your beacon can equip up to three of their available SUPPLIES . Each beacon can only bring one instance of each supply per quest. All equipped SUPPLIES are destroyed at the end of the quest, regardless of whether they were used or not.

Example: Dhalia has two sleeping bags, a titan flask, and elf cookies as her available SUPPLIES . She is preparing for a tough quest, so she wants to bring as many SUPPLIES as she can. She can only bring 3 SUPPLIES and can't bring duplicates, so she brings one sleeping bag, one titan flask, and one elf cookie.

SUPPLIES gained during the course of a quest can either be immediately equipped - exceeding the normal limit of three equipped SUPPLIES - or saved for a future quest.

Gameplay in BEACON revolves around quests. Quests are the adventures that the beacons go on, each comprising a combination of narrative and combat play.

After every quest, whether it is a success or failure, all beacons gain a character level.

Quests have the following components:

  • Ø Goal: The quest's objective.
  • Ø Stakes: The potential outcomes of success and failure.
  • Ø Information: The things known by or available to the PCs before they begin the quest.
  • Ø Rewards: The rewards, if any, that the beacons might receive upon completing the quest. Listed rewards might require succeeding in the quest, or simply completing it.

Quests progress through the following stages:

  • Ø Preparation: The beacons prepare for the quest.
  • Ø Quest Scenes: The quest begins and moves through a series of narrative and combat scenes that tell an overarching story.
  • Ø Downtime: An opportunity to undertake downtime activities before the next quest.

Chapter 10: Game Master's Guide provides guidance for creating quests (Building Quests, p. 241).

docs.title: GOAL
docs.text:
The quest's goal is the thing the beacons need to do to succeed. This can include things like:

  • Ø destroying the forces occupying the castle;
  • Ø preventing the archmage from crashing the moon into the planet;
  • Ø assassinating the leader of a faction;
  • Ø rescuing a captured friend.

The players should always know the quest's goal.

docs.title: STAKES
docs.text: The stakes describe the things that might happen if the quest succeeds or fails. Depending on the goal, this could include any of the following:

docs.title: Goal: Destroy the forces occupying the castle.
docs.text:
• Ø Success: The nearby town is safe and its people don't need to worry about extortion.
  • Ø Failure: The occupying force retaliates and destroys the town.

docs.title: Goal: Prevent the archmage from crashing the moon into the planet.
docs.text:
• Ø Success: The moon stays where it is.
  • Ø Failure: The moon crashes. Bad things follow.

docs.title: Goal: Assassinate the faction leader.
docs.text:
• Ø Success: The faction is weakened and likely to be destroyed or assimilated.
  • Ø Failure: The faction is emboldened, gaining more followers and strengthening its position.

docs.title: Goal: Rescue a captured friend.
docs.text:
• Ø Success: The beacons' friend is returned safely.
  • Ø Failure: The beacons' friend becomes the vessel of a parasitic psychic entity.

Each quest needs stakes, although the GM can keep them broad or vague. Either way, the players should have a good understanding of what the stakes are. The stakes can't be hidden or secret.

Depending on the actions of the players, it's possible to achieve a mixed outcome - neither an outright success nor a total failure. The GM can decide the results in cases like this. They don't need to be specified ahead of time.

docs.title: INFORMATION
docs.text:
Some information might be available to the players before the quest begins. This helps them prepare for the quest and understand the situation they're getting into.

Before the quest begins, the players should have an opportunity to ask questions, with the GM answering based on what they might reasonably know or can safely expect. The GM might also allow the players to perform skill checks or downtime activities to gain more information.

docs.title: REWARDS
docs.text:
After finishing a quest, the beacons receive rewards. Whether the quest was successful or not, beacons always receive a new character level , and a loot crate .

  • Ø New character level: The beacons level up after every quest they complete. This increases their character level by one and allows them to gain a new class rank. They can either take a new class at rank 1 or go up to the next rank in a class they already have (up to a maximum of rank 3).
  • Ø Loot crate: Loot crates are randomized rewards. Loot crates are an abstraction - a mechanism to assign random rewards to beacons - and they aren't always boxes of treasure. Each player receives their own loot crate containing three random pieces of equipment or techniques, one of which they get to keep. The loot they choose is added to their unlocked equipment and techniques. Players always have access to unlocked loot, just like any other piece of equipment or techniques. Each player can only receive a given piece of loot once; if a loot crate contains a piece of loot they already have, that option is rerolled. Loot crates are discussed in more detail in Chapter 10: Game Master's Guide (Loot and Rewards, p. 223).

Beacons might receive additional rewards after a request, like GOLD , SUPPLIES , or narrative benefits. These additional quest rewards might be dependent on whether the quest was successful or not. For example, the rescue of a captured prince might see the beacons awarded noble titles. Clearing out a dangerous dungeon, on the other hand, might earn each player a specific bonus piece of loot. These additional rewards are up to the GMs discretion.

docs.title: QUEST STAGES
docs.text: Quests can be broken down into three stages: preparation, the quest itself, and then downtime.

docs.title: PREPARATION
docs.text:
When preparing for a quest, the players pick the abilities and equipment they want their beacon to have during that quest. They choose the following from their unlocked options:

  • Ø A job
  • Ø A trait from their chosen ancestry (p. 68)
  • Ø Equipment (weapons and support items) equal to their slots
  • Ø Techniques (skills and spells) equal to their MEMORY
  • Ø SUPPLIES

Players always have access to all of their jobs, ancestry traits, equipment, techniques, and SUPPLIES when preparing for quests, regardless of where they are or the situation in which they find themselves.

Once everyone has prepared, the quest begins. From this moment on, they are considered to be on that quest until it is finished. They can only be on one quest at a time, although side objectives and challenges may arise along the way that weren't present when they set out.

docs.title: QUEST SCENES
docs.text:
Quests are composed of multiple narrative and combat scenes. Each quest typically features between one and four combat scenes, with narrative scenes sprinkled throughout.

The GM is responsible for presenting scenes to the players and stringing them together (see Chapter 7: Game Master's Guide , p. 84, for more information about building quests). While the GM might have an idea about how a scene could unfold, the actions of the players ultimately determine what happens within a scene.

The players are responsible for interacting with the scenes presented to them. Players don't get to choose what scenes take place (although they are encouraged to let the GM know if they have specific scenes they'd like to see), but they do influence what happens within a scene.

Example: The GM sets up a narrative scene where the beacons have to cross a heavily guarded bridge. They expect that the players will try to talk their way through; however, the players decide to solve the problem by building gliders and using magic to soar right over the bridge.

The GM did not expect this outcome, but the point of the scene was to see how the beacons solved the problem, not to force a social interaction. The players used an unexpected but creative solution.

docs.title: Example Quest Structure
docs.text:
• Ø Preparation: The beacons are presented with a quest to find a specific villain and defeat them. They prepare for the quest and set out.
  • Ø Scene 1 (narrative scene): The beacons scout for the villain's lair and contend with native fauna.
  • Ø Scene 2 (narrative scene): The beacons find the lair, but must navigate past the traps and guards within.
  • Ø Scene 3 (combat scene): The beacons confront the villain in battle.
  • Ø Scene 4 (narrative scene): The beacons flee the villain's collapsing lair.
  • Ø Downtime: The beacons return to town, completing the quest and receiving their rewards. They enter a period of downtime until they begin their next quest.

docs.title: DOWNTIME
docs.text:
After finishing a quest, the beacons begin a period of downtime . Downtime is a type of narrative play in which the characters can pursue personal interests, explore the world, and perform downtime activities (p. 27). The GM can also decide to declare downtime during long breaks in the middle of quests.

When the beacons begin downtime, it counts as taking a Long Rest , which replenishes their HP , MP , and other attributes; allows them to change out their equipment and techniques; and more. See p. 61 for more information on resting.

Chapter 4: Narrative Play contains further information on downtime (Downtime Activities, p. 27).

Narrative play is anything that occurs outside of a combat scene, whether it be planning quests, pursuing personal objectives, disabling the traps in a ruin, or even running a tavern.

The players decide what their characters do during narrative play. If the GM believes an action is important, they can ask for a skill check to determine how well it goes.

Narrative play can involve small-scale fights and conflict, like fending off back alley robbers or overwhelming a single guard. These fights are resolved in an abstract fashion, using skill checks or narrative actions (see below) rather than tactical combat. Not every fight triggers a combat scene; combat play is reserved for important, large-scale fight scenes, like fending off a squadron of dragon riders from the deck of an airship during a thunderstorm.

NPCs don't use these narrative play rules. They don't have background skills or titles, and they don't roll dice or perform narrative actions. Instead, the GM describes what NPCs do or how they react to the things the PCs do. For example, if an NPC guard wants to capture a fleeing beacon, the guard wouldn't make a skill check. Instead, the GM would describe what the guard is trying to do and let the player describe how they attempt to avoid capture. If the beacon was in a bad situation or it was clear there would be no escape, they could instead just state that the beacon was captured. In either case, the GM makes no rolls.

docs.title: SKILL CHECKS
docs.text:
Skill check summary: When you make a skill check, you roll 1d20 with the following modifiers:

    • equal to your ranks in a relevant background skill
  • +2 if you invoke your beacon's title.

When you attempt something in narrative play that has a chance of failure, the GM may call on you make a skill check to determine whether you are successful or not.

To make a skill check, you roll 1d20 . If you have a background skill that would be beneficial, you gain on the roll equal to your ranks in that background skill. Any given skill check can only benefit from one background skill. If you invoke your title , you gain +2 to the roll (see p. 11 for information on titles).

Skill checks have three potential outcomes, depending on the total of your roll and any modifiers:

  • Ø Miss (9 or less)
  • Ø Hit (10-19)
  • Ø Crit (20+)

A miss indicates you didn't achieve the desired result. You get a lesser version of what you were hoping to achieve and there's usually a significant cost you have to pay.

Example: Dhalia wants to research whether the Scourge's latest manifestation has a weakness. The GM asks Shawn to make a skill check to find out how Dhalia's research goes. She gets a 6 on her roll, which is a miss. The GM decides that instead of finding out a weakness, she learns of an ancient enemy of the Scourge. The GM also decides that she loses track of time and misses an important meeting.

A hit indicates success, but with some sort of cost. The cost isn't as severe as it would be on a miss, but it is still present.

Example: If Dhalia's result had been a hit, the GM would tell her that she successfully found one of the Scourge's weaknesses, but lost track of time and was late to an important meeting.

A crit is a resounding success. You get what you wanted at no additional cost, or you get even more than you were hoping for at a cost.

Example: If Dhalia's result had been a crit, the GM would just tell her that she found the Scourge's weakness, with no cost.

Costs for skill checks can include injuries, taking longer than expected, losing an item, damaging a relationship, embarrassing oneself, feeling a strong emotion, or anything else the GM or players can think of.

Skill checks can only be attempted at the GM's discretion. For example, if you try to jump 30 feet straight up in the air with nothing to aid you but an average level of human strength, the GM will disallow that skill check, even if you've already rolled a 25 on your attempt. Tell the GM what you want to do, and they will let you know whether you need to roll a skill check or not.
