docs.title: TELLING YOUR STORY
docs.text: By this point, you will have completed session 0. With your Reflection and Hub decided, you're ready to play the game. Next, everyone creates their characters (see p. 11) and then you can start to tell your story!

docs.title: BUILDING CAMPAIGNS
docs.text:
Your campaign is the greater story that you and your players are playing through together, usually set on a single Reflection. All the quests, narrative scenes, and combat scenes you and your players will experience are part of this campaign.

Most campaigns revolve around confronting their Reflection's Scourge. This might involve defeating it, sealing it away, or even trying to break the cycle of the Scourge forever.

When you create your Reflection in Session 0, you will probably start formulating ideas for the outline of a campaign. Keep those discussions in mind as you plan out the details of the campaign.

This section presents some tips for building a campaign and the quests that make it up.

docs.title: LENGTH
docs.text:
When planning a campaign, think about how long you want it to last. Because character levels are tied to quests, they're a great way to measure campaign length.

Are you and the players looking for a short commitment? Maybe plan on playing for 3-6 character levels. A longer campaign can go all the way up to level 12.

While it's possible to go up to level 12, your campaign doesn't need to last this long. It's perfectly possible to tell a story in a shorter time frame, and most characters can feel complete well before level 12.

docs.title: STARTING POINT
docs.text:
Next, consider what level you want the beacons to start at. By default, they start at level 1, and this is recommended for new players; however, if you have an experienced group, they might want to start at a higher level, and that's fine.

It's important to note that higher levels in BEACON doesn't necessarily equate to stronger characters. Higher-level beacons do get more ability points and GRIT , but mostly they just get more options and complexity, not raw power. Even at level 1, beacons are heroes. They're the main characters. A low level doesn't automatically mean they're untrained commoners.

docs.title: CHARACTER CONNECTIONS
docs.text:
Incorporate elements from your PCs' background skills into the campaign. Tie these characters and their stories to the broader story of the campaign, and keep doing so throughout.

Each story beat that takes place in the campaign should be connected to at least one of the PCs.

docs.title: ONE STEP AT A TIME
docs.text:
You don't need to plan out your entire campaign ahead of time. It's good to have a rough outline of where you might want it to go, but planning out every beat ahead of time can sometimes be a hindrance.

During the course of your campaign, your players will take actions that deviate from your planned story. That's fine! It's completely normal, and happens in most campaigns. That's why you don't want to waste time and energy planning out every step of the campaign ahead of time, because you will have to change those plans at some point anyway.

Plan a few steps or levels ahead, stay flexible, and have an outline of where you want the story to go next.

docs.title: BUILDING QUESTS
docs.text:
BEACON revolves around quests . The protagonists of your story will undergo a series of quests, pursuing their goals across both narrative and combat play. After each quest, they have a period of downtime before going on the next one.

Quests are like chapters in a story, with combats as the high-action peaks of that story. Quests usually contain one to four combat scenes, with narrative scenes sprinkled throughout.

Quests should always further the main campaign, even if not directly. Perhaps a seemingly unrelated quest allows the beacons to learn an important fact about the Scourge, or help them take out an important agent of the Scourge.

docs.title: QUEST STAGES
docs.text:
A story typically has four stages: an inciting incident , rising action , a climax , and then the conclusion . This is a useful framework for planning quests. All you need to do is come up with ideas for each of those four stages, and then figure out where your one to four combat scenes fit in:

  • Ø Inciting incident: This is the catchy introduction to the quest's story, which coincides nicely with the beacons' preparations for the quest. You might either tell the players what's going on, or use cutscenes to explain the situation.
  • Ø Rising action: This is the buildup of the story, defined by ever-escalating stakes and tension. Each scene builds on those that have come before. This is usually the longest part of the quest, and where most combat scenes happen.
  • Ø Climax: This is the highest point of the story - the culmination of all the prior scenes. The climax is often a final fight or confrontation.
  • Ø Conclusion: This is the wrap-up of the story, where the repercussions of the beacons' actions shine through. This usually leads directly into downtime.

docs.title: QUEST IDEAS
docs.text: Here are some simple ideas that you can use or modify for your own quests. Each quest contains examples for each of the four quest stages identified above.

docs.title: Dug Too Deep
docs.text:
Summary: Some miners dug too deep, and now the mine is swarming with monsters.

Inciting Incident: The miners unearthed a hole with no bottom. When they sent someone to explore, their animated skeleton was the only thing that returned. Monsters began to appear in the mine and the miners reported hallucinations before they abandoned it altogether.

  • Rising Action: The PCs must venture into the bottomless pit and deal with the source of these monsters or find a way to plug the hole for good.
  • Climax: The beacons must evade a giant monster, riding mine carts in a thrilling chase before the collapsing mine traps them inside!
  • Conclusion: The mine's closed for good, but that's probably a good thing considering the size of the monster that chased the beacons.

docs.title: Escort Cargo
docs.text:
• Summary: Eris Brittam, a historian and collector of antiques, needs a shipment of important cargo to be protected during transport.
  • Inciting Incident: A group of pirates recently attacked the shipment. The next stage of the journey is the most dangerous, and the pirates will definitely attack again. The cargo will next be loaded onto an airship or train.
  • Rising Action: The beacons must fend off numerous pirate attacks. As the cargo gets closer to its destination, the pirates grow more desperate.
  • Climax: Runaway train/ship! If the pirates can't have the cargo, no one can! The beacons must defeat the pirate leader and regain control of the train/ ship before it crashes!
  • Conclusion: The beacons see what happens when the cargo reaches its destination and are rewarded by Eris Brittam.

docs.title: Kidnapped Royal
docs.text:
Summary: A prince or princess has been captured and must be rescued! The royal family has an idea who might have done it, but the real reason might be surprising …

Inciting Incident: The beacons arrive at the castle the morning after the royal was kidnapped. The castle is in a state of panic as they search for the missing person, and no one will deal with the beacons until they are returned.

Rising Action: The beacons identify the kidnapper and where they went. They must make their way to where the royal is being held before the kidnapper can escape.

Climax: The beacons confront the kidnapper. If the kidnapper was in the wrong, the beacons must fight them and their companions. If the situation is more complicated, they must confront the true threat.

Conclusion: The beacons are rewarded by whoever they supported, and are offered support in their next task.

docs.title: Kill the Dungeon
docs.text:
Summary: A living, growing dungeon has been unearthed. Its rooms expand like tree roots, weakening the ground and releasing monsters onto the surface. It must be stopped.

Inciting Incident: Monster attacks have been on the rise lately, but with no obvious source. One day a sinkhole swallows up part of a city, revealing an expanding dungeon beneath. Architects confirm that where the dungeon is now, there once were sewers. The dungeon is growing.

Rising Action: The beacons venture into the dungeon, encountering the monsters and traps that spawn inside of it. They find signs of the life and intelligence that is the dungeon itself.

Climax: The dungeon focuses its ability to create monsters to forging a powerful body for itself. This living manifestation of the dungeon clashes with the beacons, attempting to purge its body of the invading heroes!

Conclusion: If the beacons win, they can kill the dungeon and stop it from growing any further. If they lose, it will grow unchecked.

docs.title: Night of the Dead
docs.text:
Summary: A town is under siege by the undead, who rise every night but turn to ash when the sun rises.

Inciting Incident: The beacons receive a direct request for aid from the townsfolk. The people of the town need help identifying the source of the undead invasion and putting a stop to it. They lose more people every night and will soon be overrun.

Rising Action: The beacons help the townsfolk temporarily strengthen their defenses, then go hunting for the source of the undead. They trace it back to the shadowy forest nearby.

Climax: The beacons make their way through the forest to confront the foul necromancer, a powerful young mage who was exiled from the town as a child.

Conclusion: The beacons either defeat the necromancer or convince them to stop. The townsfolk are relieved to be safe once more.

docs.title: Remove the Corruption
docs.text:
Summary: A corrupt political leader has been rallying the populace against the beacons and their efforts.

Inciting Incident: The corrupt leader calls for the imprisonment of the beacons. A mob of deceived citizens attack the beacons.

Rising Action: The beacons have to avoid drawing attention to themselves. They must figure out how to remove the corrupt leader and get proof of their corruption.

Climax: The corrupt leader reveals their master plan in a villainous monologue, and sets their lackeys upon the beacons! The heroes must capture them before they can destroy the evidence.

Conclusion: If the beacons get the evidence, they can regain their good standing. If not, they are forever branded as outlaws and criminals.

docs.title: BUILDING COMBAT SCENES
docs.text:
There are a number of decisions a GM has to make when preparing a combat scene. For example, they need to:

  • Ø decide how difficult the combat will be (p. 243)
  • Ø create a battle map for the combat and populate it with terrain features
  • Ø decide on the combat's battle plan (p. 244). For example, is it a simple Elimination scene in which the PCs just have to defeat all the enemies, or is it more involved, like an Assassination scene?
  • Ø decide how many NPCs will be in the combat scene, what their NPC types are, and whether they have any templates (p. 259).

The rest of this section covers these decision points, and Chapter 11: Non-Player Characters (p. 259) contains the full list of NPCs, templates, and their rules.

docs.title: SCENE DIFFICULTY
docs.text:
A combat scene's difficulty is one way for a GM to customize a fight. The main way to adjust a combat's difficulty is by increasing or decreasing the number of enemies within it.

The first step in deciding how many NPCs should be present in a combat scene is to determine your NPC budget . T o do this, take the number of PCs that will be participating in the fight and multiply that number by 1.5. For example, if you have 4 PCs, your NPC budget will be 6 (4 × 1.5 = 6).

docs.title: NPC budget = # of PCs × 1.5
docs.text:
Certain battle plans will modify this NPC budget. The Survival battle plan, for example, doubles your NPC budget. If your normal NPC budget would be 6, for example, it would be doubled to 12 in a Survival combat scene.

Every NPC you add to a combat scene costs some points from the NPC budget. Most NPCs cost 1 point to add to a scene, but NPCs with certain templates, like Minions or Mini-Bosses, cost different amounts.

NPC BUDGET COSTS NPC BUDGET COSTS 1 Minion NPC 0.25 points 4 Minion NPCs 1 point 1 NPC 1 point 1 Veteran NPC 1.5 points 1 Elite NPC 2 points 1 Mini-Boss NPC 3 points

If an NPC has multiple templates with different costs (e.g., an Elite Veteran), just take the highest cost.

Using fewer NPCs than your NPC budget allows for will result in easier combat scenes, while going over your budget will result in harder combat scenes.

Other factors can also change the difficulty of a combat scene:

  • Ø If there are more PCs than there are NPCs, the PCs have a huge advantage because of the number of turns available to them versus the NPCs. Try to design combat scenes so there aren't many more PCs than NPCs.
  • Ø Minions are easily defeated, but do just as much damage as standard NPCs. Too many Minions can quickly overwhelm the PCs.
  • Ø Mini-Bosses shouldn't fight the PCs alone. Any single character, even a Mini-Boss, is quickly overwhelmed by multiple opponents.

Ultimately, figuring out what counts as an easy, normal, or hard combat scene is more art than science because there are just so many variables. A combat scene that seems hard on paper might be very easy for your players because their builds counter the NPCs you picked. The more you play with your group and the more familiar you become with their characters, the more accurately you'll be able to achieve your intended difficulty.

docs.title: MAPMAKING
docs.text:
Combat scenes take place on a battle map , a special type of gridded map that traditionally uses square or hex spaces. You can use either type of spaces for BEACON , since the game is measured in spaces of any type. 1 space can be either 1 square or 1 hex.

This section provides guidance on how to make a fun battle map, from choosing the correct size to populating it with interesting features.

docs.title: Map Size
docs.text:
The size of the map often varies from scene to scene:

  • Ø Smaller maps usually have a longest side of approximately 20 spaces.
  • Ø Standard-sized maps have a longest side of approximately 25 spaces
  • Ø Larger maps usually have a longest side of approximately 40 spaces.

Battle plans other than Elimination assume a map with a longest side of 40 spaces or less. They can be used with smaller or larger maps, but certain battle plans might be easier or harder with different map sizes.

docs.title: Map Features
docs.text:
Combat scenes should take place in interesting places with interesting features, not small, featureless rooms.

Here are some tips for building interesting combat scenes:

  • Ø Add sections of soft and/or hard cover. Tables, trees, walls, and other elements can all be cover.
  • Ø Add obstacles or large pieces of terrain to block line of sight.
  • Ø Add places on the map that beacons can get bonuses for reaching - regaining RECOVERIES , HP , or MP ; getting a reroll on the next loot crate; and so on.
  • Ø Spice things up with environmental factors and terrain features.
  • Ø Create zones that provide tactical options for players. Getting from point A to point B might involve crossing an open field and being vulnerable to a Sharpshooter NPC. Consider adding an alternative route that is longer but protected from enemy fire.
  • Ø Mix up the size and width of pathways.

docs.title: BATTLE PLAN
docs.text:
Each combat scene has a battle plan . Battle plans provide the framework for combat scenes, determining the win conditions for the PCs, the NPC budget, and any special rules. These are designed to make combat scenes more engaging than just 'destroy all enemies' . Many battle plans feature solutions that allow scenes to be resolved quickly.

In the absence of another battle plan, combat scenes default to Elimination (see below).

docs.title: Terminology
docs.text:
• Ø Control Zone: Certain battle plans feature control zones, which are areas on the battlefield that PCs and NPCs must fight over.
  • Ø Deployment Zone: In scenes that have them, PCs and NPCs start within their respective deployment zones. Not every battle plan has deployment zones.
  • Ø Escape Zone: PCs can use escape zones to leave a combat scene. Battle plans that feature escape zones explain how they're used.
  • Ø Reinforcements: Reinforcements are characters that join a combat scene after the first round.
  • Ø Reinforcement Zone: NPC reinforcements enter the combat scene within reinforcement zones.
  • Ø Objectives: Objectives are characters, objects, or zones that the PCs must interact with in certain ways. Objectives don't take turns. They automatically fail all checks or saves, and clear all conditions, effects, and statuses at the start of each round.

docs.title: Elements
docs.text:
Every battle plan contains the following elements, which shape how the combat scene plays out.

  • Ø Map: Every battle plan contains an example map. This map is meant to represent how the combat scene should be laid out and can be used as a starting point when creating an actual battle map.
  • Ø Goal: The goal is whatever the PCs must do to achieve victory in the combat scene. Some battle plans have secondary goals, which must be completed after the primary goal to secure victory.
  • Ø Setup: The setup provides recommendations on how the combat scene should be laid out.
  • Ø Rules: Some battle plans have special rules. This section explains how they work.
  • Ø NPC Prep: This describes how many NPCs the GM should prepare and whether or not there are reinforcements. In addition, it indicates whether the PCs or NPCs deploy first in the combat scene. Whichever side deploys first must decide where in their deployment zones they want to start without knowing the locations of their opponents.
  • Ø Reinforcements: This outlines when enemy reinforcements join the combat scene, and where from.

docs.title: Acqusition
docs.text:
The beacons have to fight through enemies toward a location, and then keep their foes out. These combat scenes often involve securing a person or location held by enemy forces.

Goal: Have more PCs than enemy NPCs in the control zone at the end of Round 6.

Setup: Place a PC deployment zone along one edge of the map. Place a control zone near the opposite side of the map. This control zone is also the NPC deployment zone. It should be fortified with cover and large enough for multiple characters to occupy at the same time. Place reinforcement zones along the edges of the map.

Rules: At the end of Round 6, determine if there are more enemy NPCs in the control zone than PCs. Mini-Bosses count as 4 characters each, Elites count as 2, Minions count as 1/4, and Summons count as 0.

NPC Prep: Normal NPC budget, but half are reinforcements . NPCs deploy first.

Reinforcements: At the end of Round 1, the GM deploys all reinforcements in any reinforcement zones.

docs.title: Assassination
docs.text:
An important target has been identified and must be eliminated. Once this is done, the beacons have to safely escape.

Goal: Defeat the objective by the end of Round 8.

Secondary Goal: Defeat all enemy NPCs or escape.

Setup: Enemy NPCs can deploy anywhere on the map. Place a PC deployment zone along one edge of the map and place the objective anywhere on the map, ideally far from the PC deployment zone. Next, place an escape zone somewhere on the map, typically between the PC deployment zone and the objective. Reinforcement zones are located throughout the map, either along the edge or at locations where allies of the objective can appear, like houses or barracks.

Rules: The objective is a Veteran or Elite NPC. They should not be a Mini-Boss. When acting, they prioritize survival. Only the PCs can escape. They can do so as a free action at the end of their turn while partly inside the escape zone. After defeating the objective, the combat scene only ends when either:

  • Ø all enemy NPCs are defeated
  • Ø all undefeated PCs escape
  • Ø all PCs are defeated.

NPC Prep: 2.5 x NPC budget, but half are reinforcements . NPCs deploy first.

Reinforcements: At the start of any round before the target is defeated, the GM can deploy up to four Minions or up to two other NPCs in any reinforcement zones. Once the target is defeated, no more reinforcements appear.

BuildinG BeaconS

docs.title: Control
docs.text:
The beacons must hold locations of strategic importance like mines, food stores, or barracks.

Goal: Have more points than the NPCs at the end of Round 5.

Setup: Place a PC deployment zone and an NPC deployment zone along opposite edges of the map. The NPC deployment zone should be larger than the PC deployment zone and is also a reinforcement zone. Place four control zones, evenly spaced between the PC and NPC deployment zones.

Rules: At the end of each round, determine if either side controls any control zones. Control zones are controlled if one side has more characters in the zone than the other side, excluding Summons . Each side gets 1 point for every zone it controls. If either side controls all four zones, it gains +1 point.

At the end of Round 6, the team with the most points wins.

NPC Prep: 2 x NPC budget, but half are reinforcements . Roll a d6. On a 1-3, the NPCs deploy first.

Reinforcements: At the start of any round, the GM can deploy up to four Minions or up to two other NPCs in any reinforcement zones.

docs.title: Defense
docs.text:
The beacons must protect someone or something from hostile forces that want them (or it) dead.

Goal: Protect the objective until the end of Round 5. If the objective is defeated or destroyed, the PCs automatically lose.

Setup: Place a PC deployment zone near the center of the map, fortified with cover. Additionally, place an NPC deployment zone around the edge of the map. This is also a reinforcement zone.

Place the objective inside the PC deployment zone.

Rules: The objective is a character or object with the following attributes:

SIZE 1/2 to 2 , HP 25/30/35 , DODGE / A-DEF 10

The enemy NPCs should focus on attacking the objective. If the objective is a character or object that can be moved, then when a character begins their standard movement adjacent to it, the objective moves along with that character. At the end of that movement, the player can place the objective in any adjacent free space. If the objective is adjacent to two characters from different sides, it stops moving and won't move further. The objective doesn't move on its own.

NPC Prep: Normal NPC budget. NPCs deploy after the PCs.

Reinforcements: If any NPCs are held as reinforcements, they can be deployed in reinforcement zones at the start of any round.

docs.title: Destruction
docs.text:
The beacons have a brief opportunity to destroy a number of objectives before time runs out.

Goal: Destroy all objectives before the end of Round 8. If any objectives remain at this time, the PCs automatically lose.

Setup: Place a PC deployment zone along one edge of the map. Then, place an NPC deployment zone near the opposite end of the map and reinforcement zones along the other edges of the map.

Scatter 1-5 objectives around the map, gravitating toward the NPC deployment zone.

Rules: The objectives are objects with the following attributes:

SIZE 1 to 2 , HP = see below, DODGE / A-DEF 5

To calculate the objectives' HP , multiply the number of PCs by 20 and divide this number evenly between the objectives. For example, with four PCs, the pool of HP is 80 . With two objectives, each has 40 HP . With four objectives, each has 20 HP .

The objectives do not clear Discord and they take any ongoing Discord damage at the end of each round.

NPC Prep: Slightly more than the normal NPC budget, but not more than twice the budget. NPCs over the normal budget are held as reinforcements . Enemy NPCs deploy first.

Reinforcements: At the start of any round, the GM can deploy up to four Minions or up to two other NPCs in any reinforcement zones.

docs.title: Elimination
docs.text:
Two or more sides must fight until their enemies are defeated or in rout.

Goal: Defeat all enemies.

Setup: Place a PC deployment zone and, if there are reinforcements, reinforcement zones anywhere on the map. NPCs can be deployed anywhere.

Rules: No special rules.

NPC Prep: Normal NPC budget. Roll a d6. On a 1-3, the NPCs deploy first. If the PCs deploy first, don't surround them with NPCs - place them in interesting places, instead.

Reinforcements: If any NPCs are held as reinforcements, any number of them can be deployed in reinforcement zones at the start of a round.

docs.title: Escort
docs.text:
The beacons seek to escort someone through enemy lines. The enemy forces want this person for themselves, and will try to take them or prevent the beacons from moving them.

Goal: Escape with the objective before the end of Round 8.

Setup: Place a PC deployment zone along one edge of the map and an escape zone on the opposite edge. Next, place an NPC deployment zone between the PC deployment zone and the escape zone, and reinforcement zones along the other edges of the map.

Rules: The objective is a character with these attributes:

SIZE 1/2 to 2 , HP = 10 × SIZE (MIN 10), DODGE / A-DEF 10

Enemy NPCs should not willingly attack or damage the objective.

When a character begins their standard movement adjacent to the objective, the objective moves along with them. At the end of that movement, the player can place the objective in any adjacent free space. If the objective is adjacent to two characters from different sides, the objective stops moving, won't move further, and they are considered contested . The objective doesn't move on their own.

Only PCs can escape. They can do so as a free action at the end of their turn while partly within the escape zone. The objective escapes if they are adjacent to a PC that escapes and aren't contested.

NPC Prep: 2 × NPC budget, but half are held as reinforcements . NPCs deploy after the PCs. The PCs deploy the objective in their deployment zone when they deploy.

Reinforcements: At the start of any round, the GM can deploy up to four Minions or one other NPC in any reinforcement zone.

docs.title: Holdout
docs.text:
The beacons need to hold the line against unending waves of enemies, preventing their foes from overwhelming the space they control.

Goal: At the end of Round 6, there are fewer enemy NPCs (excluding Summons ) in the control zone than there were PCs at the beginning of the combat scene.

Setup: Place a PC deployment zone near the center of the map. This is also the control zone and should be fortified with cover. The edges of the map are both the NPC deployment zone and the reinforcement zone.

Rules: Defeated NPC units (excluding Mini-Bosses) return as reinforcements after a number of rounds equal their WOUND CAP .

NPC Prep: 3 + NPC budget. NPCs beyond the budget are held as reinforcements. NPCs deploy after PCs.

Reinforcements: At the start of each round after the first, the GM can deploy all reinforcements in the reinforcement zone.

docs.title: Raid
docs.text:
In a raid, the beacons rush to collect something, whether it be strategic resources or vital information.

Goal: End Round 4, 5, or 6 with X treasure, where X = the number of PCs +1.

Setup: Place a PC deployment zone and an NPC deployment zone on opposite edges of the map, and 1-4 reinforcement zones along the other edges. Distribute chests equal to twice the number of PCs around the map.

Rules: While in the space of a chest, PCs can open it as a minor action . Some chests might be locked. When a PC opens a chest, they gain 1 treasure.

Characters can hold any amount of treasure at once. Whenever a character holding treasure takes a Wound or Overstress, they drop all their treasure in an adjacent space of their choice. They can also willingly drop all their treasure as a minor action . Characters can pick up all treasure in a space they occupy as a minor action .

Enemy NPCs don't open chests, but will pick up dropped treasure.

NPC Prep: Normal NPC budget. NPCs deploy after the PCs.

Reinforcements: If any NPCs are held as reinforcements, any number of them can be deployed in reinforcement zones at the start of a round.

docs.title: Rescue
docs.text:
The beacons must fight their way to someone in need of rescue and safely escape with them.

Goal: Escape with the objective before the end of Round 10.

Setup: Place a PC deployment zone along one edge of the map. This is also the escape zone. Next, place an NPC deployment zone on the opposite side of the map, surrounded by cover and fortifications. Place reinforcement zones along the other edges of the map and the objective in the NPC deployment zone.

Rules: The objective is a character with these attributes:

SIZE 1/2 to 2 , HP = 10 × SIZE (MIN 10), DODGE / A-DEF 10

Enemy NPCs will not willingly attack or damage the objective.

When a character begins their standard movement adjacent to the objective, the objective moves along with them. At the end of that movement, the player can place the objective in any adjacent free space. If the objective is adjacent to two characters from different sides, the objective stops moving, won't move further, and they are considered contested . The objective doesn't move on their own.

Only the PCs can escape. They can do so as a free action at the end of their turn while partly inside the escape zone. The objective escapes if they are adjacent to a PC that escapes and aren't contested.

GettinG Started

BuildinG BeaconS

NPC Prep: 2 × NPC budget, but most are held as reinforcements. NPCs deploy after the PCs.

Reinforcements: At the start of any round, the GM can deploy up to four Minions between two reinforcement zones or two other NPCs in different reinforcement zones. A used reinforcement zone can't be used for reinforcements in the next round.

docs.title: Search
docs.text:
There is something hidden in one four places. The beacons must find it and control it before it's too late.

Goal: Control the objective at the end of Round 6.

Setup: Place an NPC deployment zone in the middle of the map. Next, place a PC deployment zone along one edge of the map and the reinforcement zone along the opposite edge. Lastly, place four control zones, one of which is secretly the objective .

Rules: Within a control zone, PCs can use their standard action during any phase to learn whether it is the objective or not. They can't do this if there are any NPCs in the control zone.

NPC Prep: Normal NPC budget. NPCs deploy after the PCs.

Reinforcements: At the start of any round, the GM can deploy up to four Minions or one other NPC in the reinforcement zone.

docs.title: Survival
docs.text:
In desperate times, survival is everything. Hide, fight, run away - all that matters is that you survive.

Goal: At least half of the PCs (rounded up) must be undefeated or all NPCs and reinforcements must be defeated by the end of Round 5.

Setup: Place a PC deployment zone near the center of the map, surrounded by cover and fortifications. The NPC deployment zone and reinforcement zone runs along the outer edge of the map.

Rules: No special rules.

NPC Prep: 2 × NPC budget, but half are held as reinforcements. NPCs deploy after the PCs.

Reinforcements: At the start of Round 3, deploy all reinforcements in the reinforcement zone.

docs.title: ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS AND TERRAIN FEATURES
docs.text: An interesting environment is a key part of a memorable combat scene. This section outlines a range of environmental factors and terrain features you can use in combat scenes, including the basic ones discussed earlier in the book.

docs.title: Environmental Factors
docs.text: Environmental factors are effects that alter combat scenes, individual spaces, or even objects. Some apply to the entire combat scene, while others affect characters in smaller areas, such as in the case of a room with poor visibility.

docs.title: COLD
docs.text: When characters within this environment take Stress from other characters, they take -1 Stress . When they take Lunar from other characters, they take +1 Lunar .

docs.title: HEAT
docs.text: When characters within this environment take Stress from other characters, they take an additional +1 Stress . When they take Astral from other characters, they take +1 Astral .

docs.title: HIGH WINDS
docs.text: At the start of each round, the GM chooses one side of the map. The winds are blowing in this direction. At the start of each character's turn while within this environment, they are pushed 1 space in the indicated direction, or 1d6 spaces if they are FLYING .

docs.title: LOCKS
docs.text:
Doors, gates, and treasure chests can all be locked, preventing them from being opened. A locked entrance - a bolted door, for instance - can't be moved through. The contents of chests and other objects that are locked can't be accessed.

To unlock something, you can make an AGILITY check as part of the action to interact with it. On a success, the lock is disabled and the object is opened.

docs.title: LOW GRAVITY
docs.text: Characters in low-gravity environments can jump further than normal. When they begin their standard movement or begin a RUSH movement while within this environment, they can choose to gain FLYING , and can move up to half their SPEED in a straight line in addition to that movement. They lose FLYING at the end of that movement.

docs.title: LOW VISIBILITY
docs.text:
Low visibility can represent darkness, fog, and other effects that make it hard to see. It affects how far characters can see, and makes it harder to find HIDDEN characters. Low visibility has the following effects:

  • Ø Characters are INVISIBLE while HIDDEN .
  • Ø SCOPE and the RANGE of all weapons are reduced by half. REACH and AOEs are not affected.

docs.title: MANA VORTEXES
docs.text:
Mana vortexes alter the cost of spells, making them more or less expensive. There are two types of mana zones:

  • Ø Mana Field: Mana fields reduce the MP cost of all spells used within them by -1, to a minimum of 0.
  • Ø Mana Void: Mana voids increase the MP cost of all spells used within them by +1. This even applies to spells that don't usually have a MP cost.

docs.title: POISONOUS
docs.text: Characters must succeed on a BULK check at the start of each of their turns while within this environment or take 1 DISCORD .

docs.title: UNDERWATER/ZERO-GRAVITY
docs.text:
Combat scenes that take place completely underwater or in zero-gravity treat all characters as FLYING . However, unless they have flight or an Aquatic Adaptation (granted by certain abilities), they can't RUSH or shift .

runninG tHe Game

docs.title: Terrain Features
docs.text: Terrain features modify spaces and terrain on the battlefield. They are not objects unless specifically indicated otherwise. While they generally affect single spaces, multiple terrain features can be placed next to each other to create a continuous feature. For example, you can have a single space of lava as dangerous terrain, but you could also connect multiple lava spaces to create a lava flow, all of which count as the same piece of dangerous terrain.

docs.title: ARMOR RACK
docs.text:
Characters can use an adjacent armor rack as a minor action , gaining one of the following effects for the rest of the scene:

  • Ø They gain +2 ARMOR .
  • Ø They gain resistance to either Physical, Force, Astral, or Lunar .

By default, each armor rack can be used once per scene.

docs.title: BALLISTA
docs.text: While characters are within a ballista's space, their ranged weapons gain +5 RANGE .

docs.title: BLESSED TERRAIN
docs.text: Characters in blessed terrain gain +1 on attacks, checks, and saves.

docs.title: CATAPULT
docs.text: While characters are within a catapult's space, their ranged and thrown weapon attacks gain Arcing .

docs.title: CHARGED TERRAIN
docs.text: Characters that end their turn in charged terrain take 5 PIERCING ASTRAL , -1 for every space they moved that turn.

docs.title: CHASM
docs.text:
Chasms have no ground beneath them, or ground so far away that characters entering them must expend great effort to return.

NonFLYING characters that fully enter a chasm immediately stop moving, take 2 STRESS , and end their turn if it was their turn. Characters that start their turn in a chasm can immediately use their standard movement to move to the nearest free non-chasm space. Otherwise, they suffer the effects of the chasm.

docs.title: COVER
docs.text: See p. 50 for detailed information on cover.

docs.title: CREEPING TERRAIN
docs.text: Any other type of terrain can be creeping terrain, allowing it to move at the start of each round. The GM determines how far creeping terrain can move, but 2-3 spaces is a good baseline.

docs.title: CURSED TERRAIN
docs.text: Characters in cursed terrain receive +1 on attacks, checks, and saves.

docs.title: DAWN STONE
docs.text:
Dawn stones are immovable objects with DODGE 5 and 1 HP . They don't cause obstruction and are auto-hit by AOE effects.

Dawn stones emit BURST 2 zones around themselves that negate the effects of low visibility. If a dawn stone is destroyed, characters within the zone must succeed on a BULK check or be BLINDED until cleared.

docs.title: DIFFICULT AND DANGEROUS TERRAIN
docs.text:
Difficult terrain is anything that slows movement, like mud, water, or thick grass. Difficult terrain has +1 movement cost.

Dangerous terrain is any type of terrain that can cause damage, like lava or thorns.

1/round , when you enter dangerous terrain or end your turn in it, you must make an ability check of the GM's choice. On a failure, you take 5 damage of any type or Stress based on the type of terrain.

docs.title: DUSK STONE
docs.text:
Dusk stones are immovable objects with DODGE 5 and 1 HP . They don't cause obstruction and are auto-hit by AOE effects.

Dusk stones emit BURST 2 zones around themselves that cause low visibility. If a dusk stone is destroyed, characters within the zone are INVISIBLE until the end of their next turn.

docs.title: EMPTY SPACE/FREE SPACE
docs.text:
A free space is a space that doesn't contain any characters or objects. Empty spaces, on the other hand, are more specific than free spaces. Empty spaces are those that don't contain any characters, objects, terrain, or terrain features.

Some abilities affect free spaces, while others will affect empty spaces only.

docs.title: ETHEREAL RIFT
docs.text: Characters that enter an ethereal rift can move through obstructions and ignore ENGAGEMENT until the end of their next turn, but can't end their turn inside an obstruction.

docs.title: EXPLOSIVE ZONE
docs.text: Explosive zones increase the size of AOEs. If an AOE would include any spaces of an explosive zone, the AOE's size is increased by +1. A LINE 10 AOE becomes LINE 11 , a CLOSE BLAST 2 AOE becomes CLOSE BLAST 3 , and so on.

docs.title: FLAMMABLE TERRAIN
docs.text: When a character standing in flammable terrain takes Astral or an AOE that deals Astral hits a space of flammable terrain, the terrain ignites (along with any adjacent flammable terrain). Characters in connected spaces (including diagonally) of flammable terrain must make an AGILITY check. Failure: They take 5 DISCORD . Success: They take 3 DISCORD . Either way, the spaces then become dangerous terrain ( AGILITY , 5 ASTRAL ) until the end of the scene.

docs.title: FOCUS ZONE
docs.text: Characters that start their turn in a focus zone take 3/4/5 STRESS if they don't use a spell that turn.

docs.title: FOG
docs.text: Fog provides soft cover to characters fully within it.

docs.title: FRICTIONLESS TERRAIN
docs.text: Characters that enter frictionless terrain or move while within it continue moving in a straight line until they hit an obstruction or character, or move out of the frictionless terrain. This is considered forced movement.

docs.title: FURY ZONE
docs.text: Characters that start their turn in a fury zone take 3/4/5 STRESS if they don't attack with a weapon that turn.

docs.title: GROWING TERRAIN
docs.text: Any other type of terrain can be growing terrain, causing it to grow by 1d3 spaces at the start of each round.

docs.title: HARPOON
docs.text:
Characters standing in a harpoon's space can use their standard action during any phase to make a ranged weapon attack against a target within RANGE 15 .

On Hit: The target takes 1D6+1 PIERCING PHYSICAL , loses FLYING , and cannot resume FLYING until this phase in the next round.

Harpoons must be reloaded after each use. They can be reloaded with a standard action during any phase, or are automatically reloaded if a character in its space reloads a weapon.

docs.title: HEALING FONT
docs.text: Characters adjacent to a healing font can regain all HP as a minor action . Once used in this way, the healing font is expended.

docs.title: HIGH GROUND
docs.text:
High ground provides benefits that represent being at a higher elevation than other characters, similar to those received when FLYING . Characters standing on high ground gain the following benefits:

  • Ø Non-thrown melee attacks against them from nonFLYING characters that aren't on high ground receive +2 .
  • Ø They neither become ENGAGED by nor cause ENGAGEMENT to nonFLYING characters that aren't on high ground.
  • Ø Their attacks gain +1 against nonFLYING character that aren't on high ground.

Accessing high ground sometimes requires special movement, like flying or climbing.

docs.title: HOLY GROUND
docs.text: When characters in holy ground would regain HP, they regain twice as much HP instead. This does not apply to characters with the Undead or Vampiric templates.

docs.title: IMPASSABLE TERRAIN
docs.text: Impassable terrain is any terrain, like a wall or a cliff, that cannot normally be traversed except by characters who possess a type of movement that allows them to do so, like flying or climbing. Some impassable terrain cannot be entered at all (e.g., a pillar that reaches up to the ceiling or the walls of an underground dungeon).

docs.title: MANA FONT
docs.text: Characters adjacent to a mana font can regain all MP as a minor action . Once used in this way, the mana font is expended.

docs.title: MONSTER SPAWNER
docs.text:
Monster spawners are objects that continually summon NPC reinforcements at the start of each round until disabled. These reinforcements are not considered part of the NPC budget. Monster spawners can be disabled with a successful ability check of the GM's choice as a minor action .

By default, monster spawners can't be attacked or destroyed. At the GM's option, a spawner may have 10/15/20 HP and DODGE 6.

docs.title: NOXIOUS FUMES
docs.text:
Noxious fumes provide soft cover . Characters that start their turn in noxious fumes must succeed on a BULK check or take 1 DISCORD , or if they already have Discord , take Discord equal to their current Discord .

Pits are difficult-to-escape holes in the ground. Characters fully inside a pit can only move to adjacent pit spaces unless they are FLYING or can teleport . Characters within a pit can use their standard movement or RUSH to move to an adjacent non-pit space.

docs.title: SLIPPERY TERRAIN
docs.text: Slippery terrain is difficult terrain . Characters that start their turn in slippery terrain must succeed on an AGILITY check or fall PRONE . Characters that ignore difficult terrain ignore this effect.

docs.title: STICKY TERRAIN
docs.text: Sticky terrain is difficult terrain . Characters that start their turn in sticky terrain must succeed on a BULK check or be IMMOBILIZED .

docs.title: TELEPORT PAD
docs.text:
Teleport pads can be one-way or two-way:

  • Ø One-Way: There are three types of one-way teleport pads, which determine their effects. When a character enters the teleport pad's space, they experience the relevant effect:
  • Ø They teleport to a specific space.
  • Ø They teleport 1d6 spaces in a random direction.
  • Ø They teleport 1d6 spaces in a specific direction.
  • Ø Two-Way: Each two-way teleport pad is connected to another. When a character enters the teleport pad's space, they are teleported to the connected pad. If the other teleport pad is occupied, the teleport fails.

docs.title: TRAPS
docs.text:
Traps are interactable objects with the Trap tag (p. 65). While many Traps are PC or NPC abilities, you can use the following Traps to represent Traps already on the battlefield.

Condition: The triggering character gains a condition based on the type of Trap . IMMOBILIZED , SLOWED , and BLINDED are common.

Condition, Area: When triggered, all characters in a BURST 1 AOE must make a save of the GM's choice. Failure: They gain a condition, chosen when the Trap is set.

Damage: The triggering character takes 6/8/10 damage of any type, chosen when the Trap is set.

Damage, Area: When triggered, all characters in a BURST 1 AOE must make save of the GM's choice. Failure: The target takes 6/8/10 damage of any type, chosen when the Trap is set. Success: They take 3/4/5 damage instead.

docs.title: TREASURE CHEST
docs.text:
Treasure chests are objects that don't cause obstruction and that contain bonus effects for the players, chosen from the table below. Players always know the contents of chests. The GM can decide if the bonuses apply to the character that opened the chest or everyone on their team. Some bonuses provide immediate effects, while others provide delayed effects or permanent resources.

Chests can be accessed with a minor action while in their space, but might be locked (see the locked environmental feature).

docs.title: UNHOLY GROUND
docs.text: When characters in unholy ground would regain HP , they regain half the HP instead. This does not apply to characters with the Undead or Vampiric templates.

docs.title: UPDRAFT
docs.text: Characters in an updraft gain FLYING for as long as they are in an updraft, or until the end of their turn if they leave an updraft.

docs.title: WEAPON RACK
docs.text:
Characters can use an adjacent weapon rack as a minor action , choosing one of the following options:

  • Ø They repair a destroyed weapon for free.
  • Ø They gain +1 on all attacks with a weapon of their choice for the rest of the scene.

By default, each weapon rack can be used once per scene.

docs.title: INFORMATION TRANSPARENCY
docs.text:
Combat in BEACON is based around information transparency. Your goal as GM isn't to hide information from your players or trick them, but instead to allow them to make informed decisions.

During combat scenes, you should always share the following information with players:

  • Ø The NPC types and templates for all enemies.
  • Ø The locations of enemies on the map at all times, regardless of line of sight or whether they are HIDDEN or INVISIBLE .
  • Ø The conditions and statuses of all enemies.
  • Ø The battle plan and all relevant goals.
  • Ø The locations of all Traps .
  • Ø The mechanics of any abilities or items that NPCs use.

Other information is restricted unless a beacon has a specific way to access it. This includes the ability scores and attributes of NPCs and the specific features they have equipped. Certain abilities, like the LORE BOOK support item (p. 218), can provide access to restricted information.

docs.title: COMBAT SCENE TIPS
docs.text:
Combat scenes have a lot of moving parts. These including creating a fair, balanced, and interesting fight for the players; designing the battle map; and controlling the NPCs during the fight.

This section contains some general, helpful tips to keep in mind when creating combat scenes.

docs.title: MAKE THEM INTERESTING
docs.text:
Combat scenes should be more than just generic battles against faceless minions. There should be stakes, reasons for fighting, and environmental features that make them interesting.

An example of a boring combat scene would be a simple dungeon room with a bunch of animated skeletons guarding the exit. A more exciting example would have the beacons finding an underground mausoleum, in which a royal animated skeleton sits atop a bone throne and attacks anyone who enters with an endlessly spawning army of lesser skeletons. These foes can only be stopped if the beacons destroy their sarcophagi.

docs.title: KEEP PLAYERS ACTIVE
docs.text: Depending on the actions players take each round, there can be a decent amount of time between their turns. Try to minimize situations that would take players out of a fight. Fill combat scenes with different things people can interact with so they have things to do other than just attacking enemies. Environmental factors, terrain features like high ground , and civilians in need of rescue are all examples of things between which players might need to split their focus.

docs.title: PLAY TO YOUR PLAYERS' STRENGTHS
docs.text:
There are a wide variety of NPC types that you can use, and some of them are strong against specific play styles.

When designing combat scenes, make sure to play to the strengths of the PCs, not their weaknesses. Use NPCs that counter PCs as a way to challenge them, not as a way to beat them. As a player, it always feels better to defeat an NPC than to feel like you aren't contributing anything.

docs.title: CHOOSE THE RIGHT SIZE AND TERRAIN
docs.text:
Every combat scene takes place on a battle map. The size of these maps may vary from scene to scene, but on average, they should be around 25 spaces by 25 spaces. This gives enough room for tight, efficient scenes.

Avoid combats in plain, open fields. Placing terrain and objects around the battlefield gives people opportunities to find cover and avoid line of sight.

BuildinG BeaconS

docs.title: PLAY SMART
docs.text:
You don't need to alter your tactics based on the intelligence of your NPCs. You're encouraged to act intelligently, attacking vulnerable characters and avoiding dangerous situations.

For example, beacons have the ability to actively defend each other using INTERPOSE or other defensive abilities. You can intentionally attack beacons supporting their allies from the back lines, because defender-type beacons will be able to step in and protect them. Unlike other games, you don't need to directly target the defender-type beacons just because they're the 'party tank' . Attack intelligently, and let your players utilize their defensive abilities.

That being said, you don't HAVE to do this. You can intentionally have your NPCs use poor tactics or make bad decisions. For example, you can play an NPC Fury as someone that only attacks the closest enemy. Just know that the game is designed around the idea that you can attack intelligently as a GM and don't need to pull your punches.

But remember: always root for your players to win.

docs.title: USE A VARIETY OF NPC ROLES
docs.text:
Each NPC type has a role, much like classes do: defender, striker, controller, and so on.

When designing combat scenes, it's best to use a variety of NPC types. This makes the combat feel more dynamic and gives the PCs more engaging decisions points. For example, if there's a Healer NPC keeping a Protector NPC alive, it will encourage the PCs to find a way to take out the Healer first.

Above all, don't put too many defenders in a combat scene. Defenders generally have high HP and low damage output, so combat scenes filled with too many of them can feel like a slog.

docs.title: USE NPCS WITH VARYING INITIATIVES
docs.text:
NPCs have set INITIATIVE scores (p. 260) and act in specific phases instead of operating according to the freeform approach used by PCs. Try to incorporate NPCs with a variety of INITIATIVE scores into each combat scene, keeping them from all clumping together.

For example, the Architect, Gladiator, and Firebug NPC types all have INITIATIVE 5 . If you have them all in a combat scene, that will slow everything down during PHASE . One result is that the PCs won't have much reason to change their plans on the fly, since they know the NPCs will always act during PHASE . Instead, consider using a Protector ( INITIATIVE 1 ), Firebug ( INITIATIVE 5 ), and Titan ( INITIATIVE 7 ). These NPC types have the same roles, but their actions are spread out through the phases.

docs.title: LOOT AND REWARDS
docs.text:
Beacons can receive additional rewards outside of their class-based rewards. These rewards might be primarily narrative, like gaining the trust or backing of a powerful organization, while others have effects in combat play, like SUPPLIES , RESIDUUM , and loot .

Loot is the most common type of reward that beacons will acquire during the game, as they'll earn at least one piece of loot after every quest.

docs.title: LOOT
docs.text:
Loot includes a range of equipment and techniques that aren't tied to specific classes. It is usually presented to the players via loot crates . A loot crate is a set of three random pieces of loot from which the player can select one to keep. The full list of loot can be found in Appendix B: Loot (p. 356).

Once a beacon has obtained a particular piece of loot, it operates like any other unlockable equipment or technique. They have permanent access to it and can choose to equip it when preparing for quests. Unless it is Unique , they can equip multiple instances of it at a time.

Loot is categorized by rarity. It can be Uncommon , Rare , or Legendary . The rarer a piece of loot, the more likely it is to have powerful effects. That doesn't mean more common items are weak, however; the power of loot is very dependent on the play style of the beacon that uses it.

Here's an example of a piece of loot:

On Crit: You regain 1 MP and your target loses 1 MP .

As you can see, ABSORPTION looks just like any other weapon. The only difference is the rarity tag, which is Uncommon in this case.

docs.title: Assigning Loot
docs.text:
After every quest, each player receives a loot crate whether or not the quest was successful.

Each player's loot crate is unique, and whatever they choose from it is tied to their character specifically. By default, players can't trade loot between each other.

docs.title: Bonus Loot
docs.text:
Whenever you feel appropriate, you can give out extra loot crates or even give players specific pieces of loot.

In the case of a narratively unique piece of loot, like a TENTACLE ROD crafted from the severed arm of a Kraken

Boss the beacons defeated, you might offer one copy to the group as a whole and let the players decide who gets to keep it. For pieces of loot that are less unique, you can give a copy to each player.

docs.title: Loot Crates
docs.text:
Each loot crate has three slots, each containing a random piece of loot. The contents of the slots are generated using either an online generator or by rolling a percentile die (d100).

Slots 1, 2, and 3 each have their own rarity scale, with Slots 2 and 3 being more likely to contain rarer loot.

The chances of a slot holding a weapon, support item, or technique are almost identical. Because it isn't possible to divide 100 by three with dice, however, techniques are very slightly more common.

docs.title: Creating Loot Crates
docs.text:
You can use this online GM sheet to easily generate loot crates. To manually create a loot crate, use the following steps for each slot, consulting the table below:

  • 1 Determine type: Roll a d100 to determine if the slot contains a weapon, support item, or technique.
  • 2 Determine rarity: Roll a d100 to determine the rarity of the slot's contents.
  • 3 Determine loot: Choose a piece of loot that matches the type and rarity results for that slot. You can either hand-pick loot or use a random number generator to generate a result using the tables in Appendix B: Loot (Type and Rarity, p. 383).

docs.title: TRADING LOOT
docs.text:
By default, loot can't be traded between players. This is to prevent players from funneling all of their loot to one person, or feeling entitled to a piece of loot someone else has that would be perfect for their own character. In short, it's a limitation meant to protect everyone's play experience.

One of the most common house rules for BEACON is allowing beacons to trade loot between each other. If you know your group and they work well together, feel free to use that approach.

docs.title: Residuum
docs.text:
Residuum can be spent to reroll the random options found in loot crates. Residuum is created with the DISENCHANT LOOT downtime activity and can be spent to apply the following effects. You can choose more than one option to apply to a single roll, and can choose the same option multiple times:

  • Ø 1 RESIDUUM : Reroll any one loot crate slot.
  • Ø 2 RESIDUUM : Reroll any one loot crate slot and choose a specific type for the slot (weapon, support item, skill, or spell).
  • Ø 2 RESIDUUM : Reroll any one loot crate slot. The rerolled slot will be one level rarer than the original result (Uncommon > Rare > Legendary).

Loot is meant to be a fun, random way of getting additional equipment and techniques beyond the ones granted by classes.

In other games that use loot as a reward, it is usually based on the GMs discretion. BEACON puts that part of the game back into the players' hands. They will always get a piece of loot, and will get to make a choice about it, even though it may not be useful to their particular build.

There are downtime activities, like SHOP , that let players trade in loot that they don't plan on using.

docs.title: OTHER REWARDS
docs.text:
The players can obtain other rewards that don't have direct rules effects through narrative play. These might include the backing of a powerful organization, an airship, or another base of operations. While these rewards shape the story, they don't have direct effects on combat.

BuildinG BeaconS

docs.title: HOMEBREW RULES
docs.text:
'Homebrew' is when you design your own gameplay elements for an existing game - like creating your own classes or equipment for BEACON !

I love homebrew, and a lot of people enjoy adding to existing games. Heck, BEACON originally started as a homebrew version of Lancer!

I encourage you to make homebrew if you're interested. Things that are especially easy to customize or create include NPC types and loot. It can be trickier to create new classes or talents because they have the potential to interact with all other aspects of the game.

Creating variant jobs is a simpler option than creating whole new classes. Variant jobs are variations of the existing jobs that players get through classes. Each class has a job of the same name. For example, the Warlord class has the Warlord job by default; however, if you designed a Valkyrie job, you could make that a variant Warlord job. When one of your players gains rank 1 in the Warlord class, they could choose to gain either the Warlord job or the Valkyrie job (but not both).

There's also room for prestige jobs . These jobs aren't tied to specific classes, but can instead be unlocked through downtime activities. This is a great way to add homebrew jobs to the game, and you can easily introduce a trainer or downtime activity to provide players with access to it.

docs.title: 11: NON-PLAYER CHARACTERS
docs.text:
Characters controlled by the GM are called non-player characters , or NPCs. NPCs can be friends, foes, beasts, or anything else that the GM presents.

In narrative play, NPCs don't roll dice or have attributes. Instead, they react to actions taken by the players.

In combat play, NPCs are characters with their own set of rules that are slightly different from the players. Bosses are a special type of NPC, meant to challenge an entire group of beacons by themselves, and have their own unique rules (see p. 323).

This chapter covers the rules that govern NPCs, as well as the specific types of NPCs that can be used in combat scenes.

docs.title: COMBAT PLAY NPCS
docs.text:
BEACON doesn't give unique attributes for every single character and monster the players might face. Instead, each NPC fits into one of several broad frameworks, called NPC types .

NPCs can be further customized with templates. Instead of having character levels like beacons, they have a tier from 1-3.

docs.title: ALLIED NPCS
docs.text: Occasionally, an NPC will fight on the side of the beacons. These allied NPCs are still considered NPCs and controlled by the GM, but are allies of the PCs and enemies of the opposing NPCs.

docs.title: NPC TYPE
docs.text:
NPC types are collections of abilities and attributes that represent general themes, similar to beacons' jobs. For example, an NPC with the Firebug type could be a fire-breathing dragon as easily as it could be a magitech pyromancer.

An NPC's type determines the ability scores, attributes, and abilities that the NPC will use. NPCs' ability scores and attributes are static numbers and aren't calculated like they are for beacons, although they can increase at higher tiers.

For example, the Cleaver NPC type has 2 BULK and 16 HP at tier 1. At tier 2, they have 3 BULK and 20 HP , which would be impossible for a beacon.

Like PC classes, NPC types fall into a few basic roles:

  • Ø Artillery: Deals damage over long range.
  • Ø Controller: Manipulates foes or the battlefield to gain an advantage.
  • Ø Defender: Protects their allies or draws attention to themselves.
  • Ø Striker: Deals damage over close-to-medium range.
  • Ø Support: Assists allies, either by healing, mitigating damage, or enhancing other characters.

The full list of NPC types can be found on p. 387.

docs.title: NPC TEMPLATES
docs.text:
Templates are additional sets of features that can be added to NPCs, which can drastically alter how they play. There are two types of templates: thematic and mechanical .

Thematic templates represent sets of abilities associated with specific types of enemies, like Beasts, Oozes, and Undead.

Mechanical templates represent NPCs that are easier or harder than normal, like a group of weak Minions or a Mini-Boss. Mechanical templates impact how many points it costs from the NPC budget to add that NPC to the combat scene.

NPCs can have multiple templates at once, although no more than two is a good guideline.

docs.title: NPC TIER
docs.text:
NPCs come in one of three tiers: tier 1 ( T1 ), tier 2 ( T2 ), and tier 3 ( T3 ).

NPCs of higher tiers are stronger and tougher than those of lower tiers. Each tier is meant to provide a challenge to characters of certain levels:

  • Ø T1: Level 1-4
  • Ø T2: Level 5-8
  • Ø T3: Level 9-12

It is possible for the beacons to face NPCs of a higher tier than their current level, but these fights represent harder challenges.

An NPC's tier changes certain values. When an NPC's rules contain three values separated by a slash (e.g., +1/+2/+3 or 5/10/15), this indicates different values used by different tiers. T1 NPCs use the first value, T2 NPCs use the middle value, and T3 NPCs use the last value.

docs.title: NPC FEATURES
docs.text:
NPC types and templates provide unique sets of features for NPCs, which are their traits, equipment, and techniques. These features come in three types: base features, extra features, and universal features . Base features and extra features come from an NPCs type and template, whereas universal features are available to all NPCs.

NPCs always have their base features equipped by default. Extra features, on the other hand, are optional abilities. When choosing your NPCs, you can optionally give an NPC 0-2 extra features from their pool of available extra features.

Universal features (p. 304) count as extra features, but are available to every NPC instead of being tied to a specific NPC type or template.

Unlike PCs, NPCs don't have equipment slots or MEMORY . They just equip whatever abilities are provided by their chosen base and extra features, regardless of their listed equipment size.

Because NPCs don't have GRIT , every ability that involves an attack has its own attack bonus. The description for each of these abilities lists the specific attack bonus to use, including whether there is any or .

For example, a Cleaver NPC attacking with their ENERGY CLEAVER weapon would roll 1d20+2 at tier 1.

Energy Cleaver FIGHT Energy Cleaver FIGHT MELEEWEAPON  HEAVYMAGITECH  PIERCING  MELEEWEAPON  HEAVYMAGITECH  PIERCING  +2/+4/+6 VS DODGE REACH 1 4/6/8 ASTRAL

docs.title: NPC INITIATIVE
docs.text:
NPCs take their turns in a different way than PCs. Instead of acting based on the phase of the standard action they want to perform, each NPC has an INITIATIVE , which ranges from 1-8. This specifies the phase in which they take their turn. During that phase, the NPC can take any action, not only those options available to PCs during that phase.

For example, Elementalist NPCs have INITIATIVE 1 . They take their turn during PHASE BOLSTER , at which time they can take any action. They can use the VOLLEY action to attack with their PRIMAL STAFF , a ranged weapon, during their turn even though it's not PHASE SKIRMISH , because they don't follow the same action rules as the PCs.

Certain templates can give an NPC multiple turns, and therefore multiple INITIATIVES . For example, the Elite template gives an NPC 2 turns each round. It takes their normal INITIATIVE and adds 5 to determine their second INITIATIVE . For example, Vulture NPCs have

INITIATIVE 3 . An Elite Vulture would have two INITIATIVES of 3 and 8 (3 + 5 = 8). Templates that provide additional turns explain when they happen.

Some NPC actions are slightly different from PC actions. The next page explains the differences.

docs.title: RECHARGING
docs.text:
Certain NPC abilities have a Recharge X+ tag.

Whenever an NPC uses a Recharge ability, it can't be used again until that ability recharges.

At the start of each of the NPC's turns after using a Recharge ability, the NPC rolls a d6 recharge die . If the result equals or exceeds the Recharge value (X) of any Recharge abilities they have, those abilities recharge.

For example, a Firebug uses Siegebreaker , a Recharge 5+ ability. At the start of the Firebug's next turn, they roll a d6 and get a 6. Because this is greater than 5, the ability recharges, and the Firebug can use it again this turn.

NPCs only make one recharge roll each turn, but that roll can recharge multiple abilities at once.

docs.title: NPC SPECIAL RULES
docs.text:
There are some additional ways that NPCs differ from PCs:

  • Ø NPCs start with WOUND CAP 1 and are defeated when they take a Wound. If an NPC has WOUND CAP 2+ , they follow the normal Wound rules for PCs.
  • Ø NPCs start with OVERSTRESS CAP 1 but they don't make an overstress roll when they exceed their STRESS CAP . Instead, while exceeding their STRESS CAP , they are VULNERABLE . If an NPC has OVERSTRESS CAP 2+ , they follow the normal Overstress rules for PCs.
  • Ø If an NPC doesn't have a STRESS CAP , they take Stress as Force damage.
  • Ø NPCs can't use the Reroll Table .
  • Ø NPCs can't SURGE .

docs.title: DESIGNING NPCS
docs.text:
When designing an NPC, do the following:

  • 1 Pick an NPC type.
  • 2 Choose templates, if any.
  • 3 Choose 0-2 extra features. Extra features can be chosen from the NPC's type, the list of universal NPC features (p. 304), and any templates.
  • 4 Choose a tier.

NPCs can look or act like anything. A Fortress NPC could be a literal walking tower, or even a giant spider.

docs.title: TINKERING WITH NPCS
docs.text:
The abilities listed with each NPC type are examples meant to be evocative. Changing a weapon from one weapon type to another (e.g., making a blade a longarm) doesn't really affect anything.

In general, you can change whether NPC features are weapons, support items, skills, or spells without

E lementalists protect their allies with magic, supporting them with arcane shields and preventing enemy access to certain areas. These units work from the back lines, lacking their own direct defenses, and are easily overwhelmed. Elementalists are also heavily dependent on MP , and negating their ability to regain it, or causing them to burn through it too quickly can cause them to waste actions.

Allies within the Fortress have no protection from AOEs and are still susceptible to forced movement taking them outside the Fortress. Although they have a lot of HP , Fortresses are VULNERABLE to Piercing damage and easily become overstressed.

docs.title: 13: TEMPLATES
docs.text:
Templates are sets of features that can be applied to NPCs. NPCs can have multiple templates, although some templates specify that they can't be combined with others.

Templates provide base features and, in most cases, optional extra features . An NPC with a template gets the listed base features and adds the extra features to the pool of extra features you can choose from, except where stated otherwise.

docs.title: MECHANICAL TEMPLATES
docs.text:
Mechanical templates are those that affect the balance of combat scenes. The MINION , VETERAN , ELITE , and MINI-BOSS are all mechanical templates.

Minions are cannon fodder - weak individually, but threatening in groups. They only cost 1/4 of a point from the NPC budget. Despite their limitations, Minions do the same amount of damage as normal NPCs, so be careful when combining them with certain NPC types, like artillery NPCs.

The toughest enemies in the game are Bosses . Unlike Mini-Bosses, each Boss is designed to be an entire combat scene in its own right - a boss battle . When your players face a Boss, they face that specific Boss and their Guardians - no other NPCs are added to the scene.

Bosses make for perfect capstone fights in campaigns or quests. Because of their unique rules, though, they should be used sparingly. Not every quest needs to end in a boss battle. Save them for important moments.

Boss battles don't use battle plans. The goal in these fights is to defeat the Boss. Additionally, Bosses don't use NPC types or templates. They are in a category all of their own, although they do have tiers of power ( T1-3 , like other NPCs).

During a boss battle, the Boss passes through multiple stages. This can represent physical transformations or just changes in tactics.

Additionally, each Boss is accompanied by a number of Guardians , which are NPC units built around the Boss's unique features.

This section introduces three specific Bosses: the Great Wyrm , the Kraken , and the Lich .

docs.title: BOSS SPECIAL RULES
docs.text: Bosses operate differently from other NPC units. This reflects the fact that they are standalone threats - fearsome challenges for any foe.

docs.title: Stages
docs.text:
Each boss battle has three stages, representing changes in the Boss's abilities and fighting style. During each stage, the Boss is essentially a new character with different ability scores, attributes, and abilities, though they always have WOUND CAP and OVERSTRESS CAP 1 .

When the Boss takes a Wound, they undergo a transformation and the next stage begins.

docs.title: WOUNDS AND OVERSTRESS
docs.text: Like other NPCs with OVERSTRESS CAP 1 , Bosses are VULNERABLE while exceeding their STRESS CAP .

docs.title: Turns
docs.text:
Bosses take a number of turns each round equal to the number of PCs in the combat scene. This number doesn't decrease when PCs are defeated. Bosses' turns alternate with PC turns just like normal NPC turns do.

Despite having extra turns, Bosses can only take one turn during each phase, except for PHASE DELAY , during which they can take multiple turns. Bosses decide which phases they take their turns in each round.

docs.title: Actions
docs.text:
During each of a Boss's turns, they can perform a standard action , a standard movement , and a minor action . Their standard action must be one available in the current phase.

Bosses have access to the same standard actions as other NPCs, but with the following changes.

docs.title: Phase Full Attack
docs.text: Full Attack: The Boss can FULL ATTACK .

docs.title: Phase Delay
docs.text: Delay: The Boss can only DELAY actions they haven't used this round. For example, if the boss has used VOLLEY , they can't VOLLEY again in PHASE DELAY .

docs.title: Reactions
docs.text:
Opportunity Attack: The boss can OPPORTUNITY ATTACK any number of times each round.

Bosses can't SURGE or use the Reroll Table unless otherwise indicated.

docs.title: Events
docs.text:
Bosses are powerful enemies that shape and alter the environment around them. These effects are called events , and each stage of a boss battle has events associated with it.

Events and their effects just happen. The Boss and their Guardians don't activate them, and aren't considered to be using them as they might an ability.

Events are tied to specific stages. When a boss transforms and the boss battle moves to a new stage, the old event ends and the new one begins.

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
Bosses' abilities change from stage to stage. Each stage of the boss battle provides the Boss with a wide array of abilities. They have every ability from their current stage equipped.

The equipment carried by Bosses don't always list a size or type. These abilities are not considered to have any size or type.

Some abilities mention a phase and its number followed by a plus sign (e.g., ' Phase + '). These abilities can be used with a standard action during any phase from the listed one onward. For example, an ability with ' Phase + ' can be used as a standard action in PHASE , , , and so on all the way up to PHASE .

docs.title: Transformation
docs.text:
When a Boss takes a Wound, they begin to transform. While transforming, Bosses still count as obstructions and are immune to all damage , Stress , and other effects until they enter their next stage. This does not affect Guardians.

Although the Boss is considered to have taken a Wound, they don't make a wound roll and are not defeated.

At the start of the next round, the next stage begins. The Boss clears all Stress , conditions, statuses, and effects, and takes on the listed ability scores, attributes, and abilities. Any events relevant to the new stage then take effect.

Although the Boss is considered the same character throughout all stages, no damage is carried over.

docs.title: Complexity
docs.text:
The SEARCH action doesn't work the same way against Bosses and their Guardians as it does against normal NPC units. Instead, each use of the action reveals one of the following:

  • Ø The target's current HP , MP , and STRESS .
  • Ø The target's traits.
  • Ø If the target is the Boss, any abilities they can take on a specific phase (excluding PHASE DELAY ), or any reactions or minor actions they have.
  • Ø If the target is a Guardian, their base features.

docs.title: Deployment
docs.text: Bosses and their Guardians always deploy first. The Boss can deploy anywhere on the map (usually in the middle), and the rules for each Boss explain when and where their Guardians are deployed.

docs.title: Guardians
docs.text:
Guardians are special NPCs that accompany Bosses. Each stage of a boss battle introduces a certain number of new Guardians. These foes persist between stages, and have the potential to overwhelm the beacons if they aren't dealt with quickly.

Each Boss's Guardians operate uniquely. Some take their own turns, while others act during their Boss's turns.

When a new stage begins, any existing Guardians gain the Guardian profile for the new stage.

docs.title: G R E AT   W Y R M
docs.text:
Dragons are incredibly long-lived creatures that grow throughout their lives. The largest and most powerful of these dragons, called Great Wyrms, are terrifying creatures imbued with explosive elemental power.

The Great Wyrm presented here is associated with fire, but you can easily change it to be associated with a different element.

Because the Great Wyrm and its Guardians can fly, the scene should have three or so harpoon terrain features (see below) that the PCs can use to deal ranged damage and bring their enemies to the ground. You can flavor them as magical stones, prepared missiles, or whatever fits for your Reflection.

docs.title: HARPOON
docs.text:
PCs standing in a harpoon's space can use their standard action during any phase to make a ranged weapon attack against a target within RANGE 15 .

On Hit: The target takes 1D6+1 PIERCING PHYSICAL , loses FLYING , and cannot resume FLYING until this phase in the next round.

Harpoons must be reloaded after each use. They can be reloaded with a standard action during any phase, or are automatically reloaded if a PC in its space reloads a weapon.

docs.title: Tactics
docs.text:
The Great Wyrm and its Guardians prefer when enemies bunch up, which makes it easier to hit them with AOE attacks and abilities. They are at their strongest when they can stack Discord on enemies and move around to catch as many enemies in AOEs as possible.

In Stage 1, the Great Wyrm is most mobile. In Stage 2, it looks for opportunities to knock enemies into Traps . In Stage 3, it becomes enraged and acts less intelligently than before.

docs.title: Scene
docs.text:
Don't set up a small or tight battlefield, as one of the PCs' primary defensive strategies will be to spread out.

Fill the map with rocks and rubble for cover and difficult terrain, and place pools of fire or lava as dangerous terrain. You can also change the environment as the scene progresses through each stage, adding more lava and cracks in the ground in the later stages.

Krakens are powerful underwater creatures that prey on ships with their powerful tentacles and storm magic. Fights against the Kraken must take place aboard a ship (see below).

docs.title: THE SHIP
docs.text:
The ship counts as an object that can't be moved. Only the Kraken and its Guardians can damage the ship, but only using abilities that specifically mention this. Instead of having HP , damage to the ship is represented by the destruction of 1-space segments. Destroyed segments of ship are replaced by water.

Beacons can repair destroyed ship segments with standard actions during any phase. Each time a beacon performs repairs, they can restore 1d3 spaces within SCOPE , changing them back from water spaces to ship spaces. They can take 1 STRESS to reroll the 1d3.

docs.title: Tactics
docs.text: The full Kraken only appears during the final stage of this boss battle. In Stage 1, the PCs fight its tentacles, which are its Guardians. The Guardians focus on damaging the ship on which the beacons fight. In Stage 2 the PCs must contend with dangerous events. In Stage 3, the Kraken appears and focuses on attacking as many enemies as possible.

docs.title: Scene
docs.text: The combat scene takes place on a 12 x 12 map, with the beacons deploying on a 6 x 6 ship in the middle of the map. The rest of the map is water, which is considered difficult terrain . Characters with Aquatic Adaptations can move normally in these spaces, but are still imperiled by the Kraken's SNAPPING JAWS trait.
